Graphical abstract The review summarizes the working mechanism, design strategies, and recent advances of transition metal-based catalysts for Li-CO2 batteries, and also provides perspectives on the challenges and key points for their future development. The Li-CO2 battery has been highly rated as an intriguing technique for balancing the carbon cycle for years, but it is still significantly challenged by the obstacles such as limited reversibility, sluggish kinetics, and poor energy efficiency. Hence, the design and development of advance catalysts that can enhance the kinetics and reversibility of the CO2 electrochemical cycling reactions are considered the imperative tasks. Transition metal-based catalysts are widely considered appealing owing to their unfilled d-orbitals, rich and adjustable valences, as well as processibility. In this review, the working mechanism and the key issues of the CO2 electrochemical cycling reaction are discussed first. Then the strategies for composition and structure design of different type of transition metal-based catalysts are highlighted, including their benefits, limitations, and the ways to implement these strategies. Finally, based on the pioneering research, the perspectives on the challenges and key points for the future development of cathode catalyst are proposed. Keywords Li-CO2 battery Transition metal Cathode catalyst Catalytic mechanism 1 Introduction The past two and a half centuries, since the First Industrial Revolution, have witnessed the massive burning of fossil fuels and excessive emissions of the greenhouse gas CO2, which have broken the global carbon cycle [1,2]. Reducing the emissions and lowering the current levels of CO2 have been well established as two significant pathways for rebalancing the carbon cycle [3–5]. Among various CO2 management technologies, the lithium (Li)-CO2 batteries stand out as one of the most promising techniques due to their inherent ability to achieve electrochemical energy conversion by directly utilizing CO2 as the reaction medium. The CO2 molecules combined Li ions (Li+) and electrons at the multiphase reaction interface (shortened from the CO2/electrolyte/catalyst reaction interface for simplicity) during discharging to produce electricity [6,7]. The above CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is generally described as 4Li+ + 4e− + 3CO2 → 2Li2CO3 + C, which outputs a high theoretical specific energy of ∼1876 Wh kg−1 with a thermodynamic equilibrium potential of ∼2.8 V [8]. Moreover, Li-CO2 batteries demonstrate high flexibility in energy conversion and storage, as they are tolerant of intermittent energy input to drive the CO2 electrochemical reduction reaction. Such high flexibility, combined with its high energy density, gives the Li-CO2 battery great promise for the controllable utilization of intermittent green energy resources such as wind, solar, and tide, by affordable storing and utilizing them in the form of electricity [9,10]. Moreover, the Li-CO2 batteries possess natural advantages and competitiveness in powering manned and sealed scientific expedition devices (e.g., submarine, spacecraft) and planetary rovers especially where (e.g., Mars, Venus) the main component of the air is CO2. From the perspective of scientific research, the study of Li-CO2 batteries can offer valuable insights into the development of Li-air batteries, as they share the same discharge product Li2CO3 [20–31]. Given that, Li-CO2 batteries have emerged as a hot research topic, and the landmark events are illustrated in Fig. 1 . In 2011, Takechi et al. found that the discharge capacity of a Li-O2/CO2 primary battery with Ketjen black (KB) as a catalyst is significantly higher than that of Li-O2 battery, highlighting the prospect of the CO2 electrochemical reduction in batteries [26]. Two years later, Xu et al. reported a primary Li-CO2 battery by using Super P conductive carbon catalyst and an ionic liquid electrolyte [25]. Based on experimental and theoretical studies, they proposed the battery discharge reaction of 4Li + 3CO2 → 2Li2CO3 + C, and this reaction mechanism is still widely recognized at present. Shortly after that, Liu et al. first realized a rechargeable Li-CO2 battery using KB as a catalyst in 2014 [24]. Hereafter, the rechargeable Li-CO2 battery configured with X catalyst is denoted as X battery for simplicity. The KB battery delivered a discharge specific capacity of 1032 mA h g−1 at a current density of 30 mA g−1. The discharge products Li2CO3 and C, and their decomposition during recharging, are systematically demonstrated by using various spectroscopic and electron microscopic techniques. After that, considerable research efforts have been devoted to rechargeable Li-CO2 batteries in the past decade and encouraging breakthroughs have been made [27,32–37]. Despite this, the Li-CO2 battery is still in its infant stage and its development faces unsatisfactory performances such as limited reversibility, poor cycling stability, and large charge/discharge voltage gap [2,6,38–40]. The inferior performance is rooted in intractable scientific issues, including (1) the high thermodynamic energy barrier for the decomposition of Li2CO3, which inevitably result in sluggish kinetics and limited reversibility of the CO2RR and CO2 evolution reaction (CO2ER) [41–47]; (2) inappropriate adsorption of reactants/products, which cause significant polarization for the CO2RR/CO2ER and pose great challenges in controlling the phase and morphology of the products, thereby resulting in difficulty in regulating the intermediate products and reaction pathways [37,48–51]; (3) the battery chemistry, which is still unclear and debatable, significantly hindering the development of advanced catalysts [35,52,53]; and (4) complex parasitic reactions, such as the solo-decomposition of Li2CO3, the degradation of electrolyte/binders, and the corrosion of Li metal anode (Fig. 2 a) [23,28,54–57]. Over the past decade, tremendous research groups have focused on improving the reversibility and kinetics of the Li-CO2 battery reaction, innovating in terms of composition and structure to develop catalysts with excellent comprehensive performance such as catalytic activity, conductivity, and mass transfer ability, thereby achieving encourage breakthroughs [58–62]. Generally, the key factors for the development of cathode catalysts are summarized in Fig. 2(b). (1) A decent catalytic performance is a prerequisite and the most core demand for advanced cathode catalysts. The catalyst should possess catalytic properties including but not limited to the following: modifying reaction pathways, altering the type and ratio of diverse species (e.g., intermediates, by-products, final products), regulating the nucleation and deposition morphology of solid products, and optimizing the adsorption and activation of reactants. (2) Considering the characteristic that Li-CO2 battery reactions involve multiple phases of reactants, it is extremely important to ensure timely diffusion of gas and transportation of charge carriers in the internal circuit (specifically, Li+) during both the CO2RR and CO2ER processes. Given that, the cathode catalyst should possess several key properties, such as sufficient wettability, a large surface area, ample pore channels, and admirable structural stability, facilitating gas diffusion and electrolyte permeation, which provides favorable conditions for maximizing the multiphase reaction interface for battery operation. (3) The transportation of electrons is essential for the electrochemical CO2 redox reactions. Therefore, a cathode catalyst with high intrinsic electronic conductivity is preferred. Otherwise, the catalysts are generally anchored onto carriers and/or mixed with additives that possess admirable electronic conductivity to gain external assistance in conductivity. (4) The advancement in key scientific issues is crucial for both the development of cathode catalysts and the practical application of Li-CO2 batteries, and similarly, the cost of these catalysts also holds significant importance. In light of this, the following principles are suggested for the development of affordable transition metal-based cathode catalysts. Firstly, comprehensively consider the cost and catalytic performance to select specific metals that offer relatively high catalytic performance at a low price. Secondly, develop massive production methods that can achieve low-cost preparation and high performance with minimal usage of metal elements, especially for noble metal-based catalysts where cost is a major consideration. (5) Environmental friendliness is a necessary condition for the green and sustainable development, as well as large-scale application of catalysts. To fulfill this requirement, the catalytic active metal elements should be non-toxic or low-toxic, and the preparation method should be environmentally friendly, safe, with low emissions, and energy-efficient. The cathode catalysts can be roughly classified into carbon-based catalysts and transition metal-based catalysts based on the categories of the main active elements. Graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNT), carbon nanofibers (CNF), and other high-specific-surface-area carbon materials (e.g., KB, Super P) and their analogues/derivatives have received widespread attention in the early development stage of Li-CO2 battery due to their advantages of large specific surface area, high conductivity, and high natural abundance [19,23,63–71]. However, the rather limited catalytic activity of carbon-based materials often results in issues such as large polarization, poor cyclic/rate capability, and low energy efficiency, thereby casting a shadow over their application prospects [59,72,73]. Inspired by other metal-gas battery systems such as Li-O2 batteries, researchers have turned their attention to transition metal-based catalysts with admirable comprehensive performance [60,74–76]. In this review, we focus on the recent advances in transition metal-based catalysts for prompting the development of Li-CO2 batteries (Fig. 3 ). We first discuss the working mechanisms on these catalysts and the critical bottlenecks that account for the sluggish kinetics and limited reversibility of the Li-CO2 batteries. Then the recent progress in optimization tactics for transition metal-based catalysts is summarized, focusing on their preparation methods, influencing mechanisms, as well as their evolutions alongside the operation of CO2RR and CO2ER. Subsequently, the challenges and key points for the future development of cathode catalyst are highlighted. This review is considered a reference for the design of high efficiency transition metal-based catalysts for advancing the development of Li-CO2 batteries. 2 Electrochemical mechanisms The essence of the Li-CO2 battery reaction is well established as reversible CO2RR and CO2ER involving both electrons and Li+ [58]. During discharge, the Li metal is oxidized into Li+ and electrons. The electrons transfer to the cathode as charge carriers through the external circuit, while the Li+ migrate to the cathode via the electrolyte as charge carriers in the internal circuit to balance the charge [10,45,59,93–95]. The CO2 molecules are electrochemically reduced by combining with Li+ and electrons at the multiphase reaction interface to form discharge products [96–98]. As a type of secondary battery system, a reversible CO2ER is expected to occur during the subsequent charging process to release CO2. 2.1 CO2RR mechanism of the Li-CO2 battery As stated in section 1, Xu et al. proposed the four-electron discharge reaction mechanism of 4Li + 3CO2 → 2Li2CO3 + C in 2013 [25]. Over the past decade, this CO2RR mechanism has been widely recognized, as the final products have been proved to be Li2CO3 and C [47,99,100]. Noteworthy, the stoichiometric coefficients of the above CO2RR are reasonably deduced based on the discharge product species of Li2CO3 and C, rather than qualified by measuring the consumption of reactants or the production of products. The specific reaction route is proposed as follows by Hou et al. [22]. (1) 2 C O 2 + 2 e - → C 2 O 4 2 - (2) C 2 O 4 2 - → 2 C O 2 2 - + C O 2 (3) C O 2 2 - + C 2 O 4 2 - → 2 C O 3 2 - + C (4) 2 L i + + C O 3 2 - → L i 2 C O 3 The above mechanism was experimentally verified by several research groups [33,56,101,102]. For instance, Qiao et al. demonstrated the above reaction mechanism by using surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) [56]. They proved the generation of C2O4 2− at the beginning of discharging and its rapid disappearance with the emergence of Li2CO3 and C with the deepening of the discharging, suggesting C2O4 2− is an important intermediate product during the CO2 reduction process. The intermediate Li2C2O4 is thermodynamically unstable and is easier to be transformed into Li2CO3 via the disproportionation intermediate Eqs. (3) and (4) [22,33,101–104]. Precisely because of this, Li2C2O4 (Li2C2O4 → 2Li+ + 2CO2 + 2e−, E = 3.01 V vs. Li/Li+) has a lower thermodynamic decomposition reaction energy barrier compared to Li2CO3 (2Li2CO3 → 4Li+ + O2 + 2CO2 + 4e−, E = 3.82 V vs. Li/Li+), attracting scientists to convert Li2C2O4 from an “intermediate product” into a “final product” [22,105–108]. Hou et al. prepared a Mo2C/CNT composite to serve as the cathode catalyst for a Li-CO2 battery, gaining a significant reduction in the charge plateau to below 3.5 V at a current density of ∼5 mA g−1 [22]. They demonstrated that the C2O4 2− specie generated during the CO2 reduction process can be stabilized as Li2C2O4-Mo2C as demonstrated by Raman and XPS analysis. Accordingly, they reasonably proposed the following two-electron mechanism for the Li-CO2 battery configured with Mo2C. (1) 2 C O 2 + 2 e - → C 2 O 4 2 - (5) 2 L i + + C 2 O 4 2 - + M o 2 C → L i 2 C 2 O 4 - M o 2 C During discharging, C2O4 2− is prevented from being further converted to Li2CO3 and C as described in Eqs. (2)–(4) by forming amorphous discharge intermediate product Li2C2O4-Mo2C, which is attributed to the metal-oxygen coupling between Mo cation in Mo2C and O anion in C2O4 2−. The above mechanism was theoretically demonstrated by Yang et al. in 2020 through first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations by contrastively analyzing the energy barriers of different intermediates during the nucleation processes of both Li2C2O4 and Li2CO3 [109]. The β-Mo2C (001) and (101) lattice planes exhibit lowest overpotential required for the discharge and charge processes, respectively, and smallest Gibbs free energy change for the nucleation of Li2C2O4. With the aid of Mo2C, the free energy change of the disproportion reaction from Li2C2O4 to Li2CO3 is increased under the aid of Mo2C, thereby stabilized Li2C2O4 as the final product. Zhang et al. proposed a *Li2O-mediated two-stage pathway for the CO2RR based on first-principles calculations on Au surfaces, which differs from the route proposed by Hou et al. as outlined above. The CO2 is initially activated under the assistance of *Li to form *Li2C2O4. In this stage, the rate-determining step is the reaction from *Li2CO2 and CO2 to *Li2C2O4. Subsequently, the *Li2C2O4 decomposes into *Li2CO3 and *CO. The latter continuously achieve *Li to form *LiCO and *LiO2 (and *C), sequentially. The formed *Li2O further reacts with CO2 to form Li2CO3 [52]. 2.2 CO2ER mechanism of the Li-CO2 battery The direct decomposition of Li2C2O4 during charging is suggested as follows [22]. (6) L i 2 C 2 O 4 → 2 L i + + 2 C O 2 + 2 e - Li2C2O4 is thermodynamically unstable and inclined to transform into Li2CO3 and C as the discharge progressing (Eqs. (2)–(4)) [22,102]. Ideally, during the charging process, the reversible co-decomposition of Li2CO3 and C should occur, releasing CO2 and generating charge carriers (Eq. (7)); the Li+ and electrons migrating back to the Li metal anode through the internal and external circuits, respectively, re-forming elemental Li and depositing on the Li metal (Eq. (8)) [9,23,110–113]. (7) 2 L i 2 C O 3 + C → 4 L i + + 3 C O 2 + 4 e - (8) L i + + e - → L i Although the reaction mechanism involving lithium oxalate as an intermediate has been the most widely reported, the reaction mechanism remains unclear and debatable, with other reaction mechanisms also being proposed. For instance, Shi et al. postulated the following mechanism (Eqs. (2)–(4)) and intermediates according to the experimentally determined discharge product species of Li2CO3 and C, where * represents a catalyst [112]. (9) ∗ + L i + + e - + C O 2 → ∗ L i C O 2 (10) ∗ L i C O 2 + L i + + e - + C O 2 → ∗ C O + L i 2 C O 3 (11) ∗ C O + L i + + e - + C O 2 → ∗ L i C 2 O 3 (12) ∗ L i C 2 O 3 + L i + + e - → ∗ C + ∗ L i 2 C O 3 Li2CO3 has a high thermodynamic energy barrier for decomposition [114–116]. The decomposition voltage of Li2CO3 is generally higher than 4.0 V owing to the overpotential associated with ohmic polarization, concentration polarization, and activation polarization [39,40,95,117–124]. In the absence of effective cathode catalysts, Li2CO3 often fails to decompose completely and remains at the cathode [19,21,125–127]. A high charging voltage is generally applied to overstep the energy barrier for the decomposition of Li2CO3 based on the Nernst equation, but usually exceeds the upper limit of the voltage window that the electrolyte can maintain stability [128–131]. In this case, complex parasitic reactions, including electrolyte degradation, conductive carbon/binder deterioration, and independent decomposition of Li2CO3 are unavoidable [73,132]. To achieve a reversible Li-CO2 battery, the discharge products Li2CO3 and C should undergo complete decomposition. In the case of a battery that decomposes Li2CO3 alone, it is deemed rechargeable but not reversible, despite the decomposition of a key discharge product for Li-CO2 batteries. The self-decomposition reaction of Li2CO3 is indeed a catastrophic side reaction for Li-CO2 batteries, as its decomposition products encompass oxidizing substances such as oxygen and superoxide radicals, which can further assault other battery components like the electrolyte, triggering secondary side reactions including electrolyte decomposition. For instance, Yang et al. prepared a Li2CO3-preloaded electrode with 12C and 13C carbon as conductive agents to detect the evolved gas while charging the simulated battery configured with the preloaded electrode [21]. They found that the preloaded Li2CO3 decomposed independently to release CO2, superoxide radicals, and dissolved oxygen upon charging, and the latter two causes the decomposition of the tetraglyme electrolyte solvent. Solid-state electrolyte, gel electrolyte, and inorganic molten salt-based electrolyte have been proposed and show great promise since they contain less or no reactive organic solvents. Tremendously advanced catalysts such as MnO, Ni, Ru, and RuRh alloy have been demonstrated effective for enabling high reversibility of Li-CO2 batteries [18,23,88,89]. Xing et al. found the particle sizes of the discharge products generated on the RuRh/VC72 cathode are relatively smaller than those formed on the VC72 cathode at the same discharge depth [89]. This is attributed to the additional and preferred RuRh active sites, which facilitate the nucleation of discharge products. During the charging process, the discharge products on the RuRh/VC72 cathode can be effectively decomposed, whereas some of them are remained on the VC72 cathode. Yang et al. assembled a sputtered Au battery and a sputtered Au-Ru battery to understand the efficacy of Ru in driving CO2 redox reactions by using in situ SERS [23]. They found the Au-Ru electrode could promote the co-decomposition of Li2CO3 and C, whereas Au electrode could not, thereby highlighting the effectiveness of Ru in enhancing the battery reversibility. The remaining Li2CO3 and solid by-products colonized the catalyst surface, resulting in a gradual decrease in the accessible active sites on the catalyst, which is also known as catalyst poisoning, thereby further reducing catalyst activity and deteriorating mass transfer and electron transport [7,10,54]. The above analyses revealed that the CO2 electrochemical reduction and evolution reaction mechanism is profoundly shaped by the choice of electrocatalysts. Therefore, the development of efficient catalysts that can modulate the discharge products to non-Li2CO3 species (e.g., L2C2O4) and/or effectively reduce the energy barrier of the CO2ER is crucial for advancing the development of Li-CO2 batteries [1,58]. We delve into and highlight the recent advances in the realm of transition metal-based electrocatalysts for Li-CO2 batteries as schematically illustrated in Fig. 3. 3 Metals and their alloys The cathode catalyst should be able to effectively adsorb and activate CO2 during discharge, promote the deposition of discharge products on its surface, and drive the simultaneous decomposition of discharge products Li2CO3 and C during charging [1,7,118,133]. The electronic configuration has a direct impact on the adsorption and activation of reactants as well as the decomposition of discharge products, and is therefore considered as a quasi-descriptor for the CO2RR/CO2ER activity of cathode catalysts in Li-CO2 batteries [14,15,134,135]. Transition metals are characterized by their high intrinsic conductivity, unfilled d-orbitals, rich and adjustable valence states, as well as processibility, and thus exhibit high application potential in the field of Li-CO2 batteries [60,136–141]. 3.1 3d transition metals Given the Li-CO2 battery realizes the electrochemical energy conversion through the CO2RR/CO2ER involving both electrons and Li+ at the multi-phase reaction interface [103,106,142,143]. Therefore, the cathode catalyst should have not only high catalytic activity but also a certain pore structure to meet the mass transfer needs of gas diffusion and electrolyte penetration, high electronic conductivity to promote electron transport, and a large specific surface area to achieve a high density of active sites and promote rapid and large-scale nucleation and uniform deposition of discharge products [3,144]. To achieve the above goals, transition metals are generally loaded on conductive, light-weight, and low-cost carbon-based carriers for obtaining a high specific surface area, high active site density, and high atomic utilization rate [107,147–149]. The common carbon materials such as graphene, CNT, CNF, KB, Super P are widely used as carriers for transition metal catalysts due to their high specific surface area, porous structure, or ease of constructing porous structures [13,14,18,22,23,49,85,87,89,90,145,147,150–154]. For instance, Zhang et al. loaded adjacent Co atoms onto GO (adjacent Co/GO) by rapid freezing of a CoCl2 aqueous solution dispersed with graphene oxide (GO) in liquid nitrogen, followed by freeze-drying and N2/H2 thermal reduction [145]. The high-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image in Fig. 4 (a) shows various adjacent Co (highlighted with red circles) are formed on GO. They found that, by statistically analyzing 100 Co samples, the distance between adjacent Co dots fell within the range of approximately 1.20–2.54 Å. The large specific surface area of GO is beneficial to obtaining a high density of Co active sites, and it is easy to wrinkle to form a pore structure conducive to mass transfer. The adjacent Co/GO delivers a discharge specific capacity of up to 17538 mA h g−1, along with significantly better stability than single-atom Co/GO or Co nanoclusters/GO. DFT calculations show that the adjacent Co/GO has stronger Li2CO3 adsorption ability compared to single-atom Co or GO, which can effectively promote the deposition and decomposition of Li2CO3 during discharging and charging, respectively (Fig. 4b and c). Similarly, Zhang et al. prepared nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) loaded with Ni nanoparticles through solvothermal chemical reduction and subsequent heat treatment [18]. The high angle toroidal dark field (HAADF)-STEM image in Fig. 4(d) demonstrates that tremendous white particles are obviously anchored on graphene. They found that the discharge specific capacity and cycle stability of the Ni-NG batteries were significantly higher than those of the ones constructed with graphene catalyst. First-principles calculations showed that the Ni(111) and Ni(200) can both effectively adsorb Li, and the optimized adsorption energy for CO2 on Ni(111) and Ni(200) are −0.36 and −0.54 eV, respectively (Fig. 4e and f). These results suggest that the Ni nanoparticles mounted on Ni-NG can capture and supply the reactants of CO2 and Li, and act as active centers for catalyzing the CO2RR during discharging. The elemental Cu is prone to be oxidized at higher voltages (>3.0 V), which is an important reason for its exclusion as the cathode current collector in lithium-ion batteries. Therefore, when Cu is used as a catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries, it will inevitably be oxidized to form oxides [7,21,126]. Zhang et al. prepared a composite of Cu nanoparticles highly dispersed on N-doped graphene (Cu-NG) as shown in Fig. 4(g) [126]. The elemental Cu in Cu-NG underwent surface oxidation without any doubt during the charging and discharging process of the Cu-NG battery. They used XPS to study the evolution of Cu and found that the binding energy of Cu in initial discharged and initial charged Cu-NG did not show obvious shifting compared to that of the original one. However, after 10 cycles, the binding energy of Cu 2p shifted to higher energy levels. They believed that the two peaks at 934.1 and 953.7 eV of the Cu-NG catalyst retrieved after the 10th charging should be attributed to CuO. TEM was used to further observe and study the retrieved Cu-NG catalyst after its 10th charging, revealing that a CuO layer with a thickness of 3–5 nm had formed on the surface of the elemental Cu particles, as shown in Fig. 4(h). Based on the above experimental results, they proposed the following hypotheses: (1) The CO2ER during the first discharge did not produce strongly oxidizing intermediates that could oxidize Cu nanoparticles; (2) When the charging potential exceeds a certain value (around 4.4 V), a self-decomposition reaction of Li2CO3 occurs, producing superoxide radicals O2 •−: Li2CO3 → 4Li+ + 2CO2 + O2 •− + 4e−; (3) Metal particles can promote the co-decomposition reaction of Li2CO3 and C, but the Cu-NG catalyst does not directly possess this ability in Li-CO2 batteries. Instead, it is only after the formation of a CuO layer on the surface of Cu nanoparticles that the reversibility of the Li-CO2 battery reaction is achieved (Fig. 4i). Different from all the above-mentioned metals, Kim et al. reported that Fe undergoes reversible redox reactions when used as a cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries [146]. They prepared nitrogen-doped CNT (Fe NPs@N-CNT) embedded with Fe nanoparticles (NPs) through the thermal decomposition and reduction of a composite of CNT and hemoglobin (Hb). The preparation process is schematically illustrated in Fig. 4(j). XPS was used to investigate the role of Fe in the Fe NPs@N-CNT catalyst. The binding energies of Fe in the Fe NPs@N-CNT catalyst were approximately 720 eV (Fe 2p 1/2) and ∼710 eV (Fe 2p 3/2), indicating that Fe exists in the elemental form in the Fe NPs@N-CNT catalyst. Distinct Fe–O–C related signals were observed in the O 1s and Fe 2p spectra of the pristine Fe NPs@N-CNT electrode (Fig. 4k and l). After discharging, the Fe–O–C related signals significantly weakened, and the Fe 2p spectrum showed signals associated to Fe0, which should originate from the breakage of Fe–O–C bonds and the release of CO2 to form Li2CO3. During the subsequent charging process, Fe0 was reconverted to Fe–O–C. The above researches indicate that the 3d transition metals Fe, Ni, Co, and Cu can all promote the CO2RR/CO2ER in Li-CO2 batteries, but show quite different mechanisms of action. Zn has also been reported for use as a cathode catalyst in aqueous Li-CO2 batteries [155]. Xie et al. prepared 3D porous fractal zinc (PF-Zn) using a repeated process of cathodic deposition/anodic oxidation [155]. A three-electrode aqueous Li-CO2 battery was assembled using the as-prepared PF-Zn as the catalyst, a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution as the electrolyte, Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode, and a Pt mesh as the counter electrode. They demonstrated that the discharge products were CO and Li2CO3. Accordingly, a reaction pathway for the battery is proposed as 2Li+ + 2CO2 + 2e− → Li2CO3 + CO, achieving a maximum Faraday efficiency of 67%. The protonic primary Li-CO2 battery based on aqueous electrolytes is out of the scope of this review and thus not discussed in detail here. 3.2 4d and 5d transition metals The 4d and 5d transition metals are generally disadvantaged in their natural abundance when compared with the 3d transition metals. Yet they are highly rated in almost all fields related to catalysis due to their more stable chemical properties, higher catalytic activity, and durability [16,156–164]. Yang et al. anchored Ru nanoparticles on Super P carbon by using a solvothermal method and utilized the as-prepared Ru@Super P nanocomposite as a cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 battery [23]. The Ru@Super P battery exhibited significantly better catalytic activity than the one configured with Super P catalyst. The Ru@Super P battery could stably cycle for 80 cycles at 100 mA g−1, and it could still stably cycle for 70 cycles even when the current density was raised to 200 mA g−1 or 300 mA g−1 (Cutoff capacity: 1000 mA h g−1; Voltage window: 2.0–4.4 V). In situ SERS was employed to evaluate the catalytic activity of Ru in facilitating the co-decomposition of Li2CO3 and C by using sputtered Au electrode and Au-Ru electrode. As shown in Fig. 4(m and n), only signals related to tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME, the solvent of the electrolyte) were observed in both electrodes in their original state. Upon discharging, two peaks emerged at 1080 and 1580 cm−1, which can be attributed respectively to Li2CO3 and the G band of elemental C. Their intensity increased as discharging deepened. They suggest that the absence of the D band of elemental C is due to the overlap and merging of this characteristic peak with the peak related to TEGDME at 1289 cm−1. For the Au-Ru electrode, the peaks at 1080 and 1580 cm−1 gradually weakened during the subsequent charging process and almost vanished after the charging ended. In contrast, on the Au electrode, only the peak of Li2CO3 gradually weakened upon charging, while the intensity of the G band of elemental C did not show any obvious change through the whole charging process. Based on the above results and analysis, they believe that the Ru catalyst can effectively promote the reaction between Li2CO3 and C during the charging process as schematically illustrated in Fig. 4(o), thereby improving the reversibility of the Li-CO2 battery reaction. Ir is another important noble metal catalyst that has been demonstrated in other catalysis fields such as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and Li-O2 batteries due to its high physical/chemical stability and catalytic activity [16,31,157,163,165]. Song et al. prepared Li2CO3 preloaded B4C/Ir and B4C electrodes, and found that the Ir/B4C electrode can decompose Li2CO3 at a voltage lowered to 4.37 V, while the B4C can oxidize only 4.7% of the preloaded Li2CO3 [31]. The Li-O2 battery using Ir/B4C as a cathode catalyst shows much improved cyclability compared to that configured with a B4C catalyst, which is reasonably attributed to the complete decomposition of Li2CO3 under the catalysis of Ir. This study highlights the feasibility of Ir as a cathode catalyst for a Li-CO2 battery. Xing et al. loaded wrinkled Ir nanosheets onto N-doped carbon nanofibers (Ir NSs-CNFs) and applied them as cathode catalyst in Li-CO2 batteries, achieving distinctly better electrochemical performance than CNFs electrodes [16]. To clarify the role of the Ir NSs-CNFs catalyst, the authors conducted a detailed comparative study on the phase composition and morphological evolution of discharge products on Ir NSs-CNFs and CNFs catalysts. The CNFs electrode forms a thin layered Li2CO3 discharge product with a thickness of ∼400 nm when discharged to 0.5 mA h cm−2. The discharge product further deposits as the discharge depth increases and eventually completely covers the electrode surface when the battery reaches the voltage cutoff condition. In sharp contrast, the Ir NSs-CNFs electrode deposits amorphous granular discharge products of about 200 nm at shallow discharge depths (0.5 and 1.0 mA h cm−2) and converts into the same thin layered Li2CO3 discharge product as the CNFs electrode at the end of discharge. Based on this, they infer that the amorphous granular discharge product formed at lower discharge depths on the Ir NSs-CNFs electrode is Li2C2O4 and characterize this discharge product using various spectroscopic techniques. Interestingly, in another study on the use of RuRh alloy nanosheets as catalysts for Li-CO2 batteries, they found that Rh, which is adjacent to both Ru and Ir in the periodic table, has almost no activity towards CO2RR and CO2ER (detailed in Section 3.3) [89]. 3.3 Monodispersed metals, alloys, and intermetallic compounds As mentioned above, cathode catalysts based on single transition metal elements exhibit excellent performance in Li-CO2 batteries. By introducing another metal element, it is expected to achieve synergistic catalysis of the two elements, achieving a “1 + 1＞2″ gain effect [89,90]. According to the combination form of metal elements, such bimetallic catalysts mainly exist as monodispersed metals, solid solution alloy (SSA), and intermetallic compound (IMC) [8,14,21,36,89,90,166–173]. Single-component catalysts generally have an advantage in promoting one side of the CO2 recycling reactions, namely CO2RR or CO2ER. The engineering of bi-component materials provides a possibility for integrating either CO2RR or CO2ER catalytic capabilities in one catalyst, which is generally known as a bifunctional catalyst [140,174–176]. Zhou et al. designed a 4H/fcc Ru-Ni heterojunction under the guidance of DFT calculations as bifunctional cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries (Fig. 5 a) [32]. They selected five noble metals (Ru, Ir, Pd, Pt, and Rh) and four non-precious ones (Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn) as the candidates by comprehensively considering their abundance, cost, and utilization in metal-gas batteries. Among these candidate elements, Ru is considered as the preferred one owing to its stronger adsorption energies for both the reactants and the discharge products, which is beneficial to both the activation of reactants and the uniform deposition and decomposition of the discharge products (Fig. 5b–d). Moreover, Ni is determined as the adequate one for serving as CO2ER centers based on the same consideration as it shows a moderate affinity towards Li2CO3 and preferred low adsorption towards Li and CO2, which is favor for the rupture of the Li–O bond in Li2CO3 and also for the release of Li and CO2. By altering the chemical microenvironment of surface catalytic elements, the electronic structure of the active sites can be modified. This modification subsequently modulates the adsorption mode and activation energy of reactants, enhances electronic conductivity, optimizes the adsorption of products to direct their deposition and facilitate subsequent decomposition, reduces the decomposition barrier of discharge products, and ultimately improves the kinetics for CO2RR/CO2ER [170–176]. Generally, the electronic structure of a parent metal can be effect by combing with a foreign one owing to the interaction of the electron cloud around the heterogeneous metal atoms, endowing the bimetallic catalyst with unique synergistic catalysis [21,32,172]. For example, Zhang et al. loaded both Ru and Cu nanoparticles on graphene (Ru-Cu-G) as a cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries. There are numerous white particles anchored on the layer of Ru-Cu-G [117]. HRTEM image shows that no obvious agglomeration occurs between these Ru/Cu particles, and the Ru and Cu do not exist in the form of alloys but are distributed separately on graphene. They used XPS to comparatively study the changes in the binding energies of Cu and Ru during charging and discharging for three catalysts: Ru-Cu-G, graphene loaded with Cu nanoparticles (Cu-G), and graphene loaded with Ru nanoparticles (Ru-G). The binding energies of Ru and Cu in the first discharged Ru-Cu-G electrode did not show distinct change relative to the pristine one. After the first charge, the binding energy of Cu changed slightly, while the binding energy of Ru remained unchanged. However, the Ru in Ru-G showed a significant blue-shift after the first charge. After the 10th charging, peaks observed at 942.0 eV and 285.2 eV can be ascribed to the Cu and Ru oxides generated during the repeated charging/discharging processes. Based on these results, they believe that the interaction between Ru and Cu in Ru-Cu-G triggers distortion in the electron cloud around the metal atoms, thereby affecting the binding energy of each other during the electrochemical process, giving Ru and Cu a synergistic effect and enhancing battery performance. By kneading two or more metals into alloys, it is expected to obtain significantly different atomic arrangements, chemical bonds, and electronic structures compared to their single metal counterparts [8,14,36,89,90,167–171,177–181]. The lattice mismatch changes the electronic structure or d-band center of each metal, thereby endowing the alloy with alloying effects such as coordination effects and stress effects [166,178]. The SSAs can be classified into dual-active-component and single-active-component ones based on the activity of each metal component. Xing et al. synthesized triangular RuRh SSA nanosheets with a thickness of 1.9 ± 0.5 nm and a side length of approximately 16.3 nm using a wet-chemical reduction method using oleylamine as solvent and surfactant (Fig. 5e and f) [89]. The Ru to Rh ratio in the RuRh SSA is determined to be 85:15 by using EDS and ICP-AES (Fig. 5g). The phase of the RuRh SSA has been demonstrated to hcp-Ru, indicating the Rh atoms have diffused into the lattice of Ru to form a RuRh SSA (Fig. 5g). They mixed these nanosheets with conductive carbon black VC72 to prepare RuRh/VC72 as cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries. At 200 mA g−1, the RuRh/VC72 battery exhibited an average charging voltage of approximately 3.75 V, while the corresponding value for the pure VC72 electrode was approximately 4.20 V, indicating that the RuRh catalyst can effectively reduce the charging overpotential and promote the decomposition of Li2CO3. The RuRh/VC72 battery demonstrated a charge-end-voltage below 3.96 V, whereas the VC72 electrode initiated the voltage cutoff after just 24 cycles. In addition, they evaluated Rh/VC72 and Ru/VC72 electrodes under the same conditions and found that the Rh/VC72 electrode did not significantly improve performance compared to the pure VC72 electrode, while the Ru/VC72 electrode showed distinctly better performance than the pure VC72 electrode. That is, the RuRh alloy is a single-active-component SSA catalyst. XPS was used to study the elemental electronic structure in the RuRh SSA. As shown in Fig. 5(h and i), the binding energy of Ru in RuRh/VC72 is obviously negatively shifted compared to that of Ru in Ru/VC72, while the Rh peak exhibits a significant blue-shift compared to the Rh peak in Rh/VC72. Therefore, in the RuRh SSA, the low-electronegative Rh inclines to transfer electrons to the high-electronegative Ru, giving Ru a much higher electronegativity and better catalytic activity. Some other SSAs such as RuCu, RuCo, RuNi, CoNi, and IrRu were demonstrated as dual-active-component catalysts [14,89,90,166–169,171]. Jin et al. kneaded the thermodynamically immiscible Ru and Cu into intermixed Ru-Cu single-phase SSA nanoparticles and uniformly dispersed them onto carbon nanofibers (denoted as i-RuCu/CNFs) through solvothermal method and subsequent heat treatment [14]. It was found that when the stoichiometric ratio of Ru to Cu in the SSA was 4: 1, the prepared i-Ru4Cu/CNFs exhibited the best performance in Li-CO2 batteries. The diffraction peaks of the i-RuCu/CNFs are almost the same to the Ru/CNFs, but are slightly shifted toward high angles, which indicate the success incorporation of Cu atoms into the lattice of Ru to form RuCu SSA. XPS tests showed that the binding energies of Cu and Ru in i-Ru4Cu/CNFs exhibited blue-shift and red-shift, respectively, indicating that electrons tend to migrate from Cu with lower electronegativity to highly electronegative Ru, thereby giving Ru in the RuCu SSA higher electronegativity and higher catalytic activity (Fig. 5j and k). They comparatively studied the electrochemical performance of i-Ru4Cu/CNFs, Cu/CNFs, and Ru/CNFs in Li-CO2 batteries. Benefiting from the alloying effect between Ru and Cu in the i-Ru4Cu SSA, i-Ru4Cu/CNFs battery exhibited smaller charge/discharge voltage gap, higher discharge specific capacity, and better cycling stability compared to those configured with the other two catalysts. They also prepared Ru82Co18 SSA/CNFs using a similar method [90]. In the Ru82Co18 SSA, Co tends to donate electrons to Ru, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of Ru. The Ru82Co18 SSA/CNFs showed significantly better catalytic performance than Ru/CNFs in Li-CO2 batteries. Wang et al. prepared a Ir-Ru nanoalloy/nitrogen-doped CNTs (IrRu/N-CNTs) composite through a simple solvothermal method [167]. The CV curve of the IrRu/N-CNTs battery depicts two anodic peaks at 4.05 and 4.26 V, which are similar to the anodic peaks of Ir/N-CNTs battery and Ru/N-CNTs battery, respectively (Fig. 5l), indicating the electrochemical decomposition of Li2CO3 is a two-step process as shown in Fig. 5(m). In the initial stage, the Li2CO3 independently decomposed at the Ir-dominated active centers. Subsequently, the Li2CO3 reversibly decomposed at Ru-dominated active center with C. IMCs are considered a special type of alloy [182–184]. They are featured with long-range ordered atomic arrangements, fixed stoichiometric ratios, and controllable crystal structures, generally exhibiting better catalytic performance relative to SSAs [185,186]. Despite this, the employment of IMCs as catalysts lags behind SSAs, primarily hindered by intricate synthetic barriers in crafting nanoscale IMC structures with high surface areas [183,184,187–189]. The preparation of atomically ordered IMCs necessitates substantial energy inputs, typically achieved through high-temperature annealing, which inherently leads to particle agglomeration, distinctly reducing the catalytically active area [185,190,191]. Consequently, innovating in highly efficient synthetic methodologies is crucial for producing high-surface-area IMC nanostructures, which is significant for catalytic applications [187,192]. Jian et al. prepared a Ni3Al/Ni heterojunction (NP-Ni3Al/Ni) with a spongy structure by using a dealloying strategy and used it as cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries [10]. The NP-Ni3Al/Ni presented a 3D bicontinuous nanoporous structure with uniform ligaments/pores. The rich pore structure of NP-Ni3Al/Ni offers abundant channels for mass transfer, continuous metal skeleton for electron transport, and large surface area for achieving more active sites, accessible multiphase reaction interfaces, and deposition space for discharge products. The co-existence of Ni3Al and Ni phases is demonstrated by HRTEM (Fig. 5n). Moreover, XPS tests showed that the binding energies of Ni and Al in NP-Ni3Al/Ni shifted toward lower and higher energy levels, respectively, indicating that electrons migrate from Al to Ni, thereby giving Ni higher electronegativity and higher catalytic activity. DFT theoretical calculations showed that the strong interaction between Al and Ni in the Ni3Al IMC enhances the adsorption of reactants and products on NP-Ni3Al/Ni. Moreover, compared to pure Ni, the Ni3Al/Ni heterojunction can more effectively reduce the energy barriers of intermediate reaction steps during charging, which is conducive to promoting the co-decomposition reaction of Li2CO3 and C during the charging process (Fig. 5o). Thanks to the synergistic advantages in structure and composition, the NP-Ni3Al/Ni battery exhibited significantly improved cycling and rate performance compared to that configured with nanoporous Ni (NP-Ni) catalyst. At 250 mA g−1, both NP-Ni3Al/Ni and NP-Ni batteries can cycle for 35 cycles when the cutoff capacity was set to 1000 mA h g−1. However, when the cutoff capacity was raised to 2500 mA h g−1, NP-Ni battery triggered the voltage cutoff, while NP-Ni3Al/Ni could continue to cycle for another 67 cycles, ultimately achieving a total cycle lifespan of 1620 h. In addition, they reported an interpenetrating trimodel nanoporous RuAl/Ru heterojunction (NP-RuAl/Ru), which exhibited distinctly superior intrinsic catalytic activity and durability compared to Ru for Li-CO2 batteries [54]. They investigated the adsorption of various reactants and products on three models: RuAl(011)/Ru(001) heterojunction, RuAl(011), and Ru(001) by using DFT calculations. All three models exhibited moderate adsorption of Li, indicating their ability to supply Li for the CO2RR. For the CO2RR, strong adsorption of CO2 is a necessary condition for its capture and activation. Thanks to the incorporation of Al, the RuAl/Ru heterojunction possesses abundant nano-heterogeneous interfaces, which augment highly active catalytic sites and drive charge redistribution in the heterostructure, enhancing the adsorption of CO2. Moreover, the RuAl/Ru heterojunction exhibits significantly high adsorption energy for Li2CO3, favoring its uniform deposition on the cathode catalyst. For the CO2ER, the dissociation of Li–O bonds with high binding energy is crucial for the decomposition of Li2CO3. In the first two intermediate steps related to Li+ dissociation, RuAl(011) exhibits a lower Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) compared to Ru(001). The RuAl(011)/Ru(001) heterojunction can further reduce the ΔG of the intermediate steps related to Li+ dissociation. Additionally, compared to RuAl(011), the RuAl(011)/Ru(001) heterojunction also exhibits a lower ΔG in the intermediate step of converting *CO3 and *C into *CO2 and *CO. These results indicate that RuAl/Ru can reduce the thermodynamic barriers of the co-decomposition reaction of Li2CO3 and C, thus significantly improving the intrinsic catalytic activity for the CO2ER. Moreover, the hierarchical porous metallic skeleton with abundant nano-heterointerfaces can provide rich active sites, smooth mass and electron transfer channels, and sufficient space for the deposition of discharge products. The NP-RuAl/Ru catalyst can sustain cycling for 1400 h at 200 mA g−1 and exhibits a polarization lowered to ∼1.25 V. The proposed strategy of achieving “synchronous reconstruction of phases and structures” based on dealloying provides a new paradigm for the design of IMC electrocatalysts for high-performance Li-CO2 batteries. 4 Metal compounds 4.1 Metal oxides and hydroxides Transition metal oxides (TMO) are considered promising candidates for enhancing the activity of CO2RR/CO2ER as the d-orbitals of metal cations are prone to gaining or losing electrons, thus impelling the CO2 electrochemical recycling reactions [136,193,194]. Moreover, TMOs are generally characterized by adjustable valences and structures, low cost, low toxicity or non-toxicity, and high natural abundance [195–198]. However, their poor conductivity and inert electronic structure pose significant obstacles to achieving further improvements [93,135,199–201]. Currently, a variety of tactics, including morphology control, defect engineering, and interface engineering, have been proposed and demonstrated to be effective for improving the performance of TMOs [88,150,193,202–209]. Miniaturization of the smallest unit of TMO catalysts is considered an effective strategy for not only reducing the usage of metals, but also for enhancing the activity of these catalysts [88,205,212,213]. Li et al. dispersed MnO nanoparticles in a graphene-interconnected N-doped 3D carbon framework (MnO@NC-G) by pyrolyzing a nanocomposite of a Mn-based metal-organic framework (MOF) wrapped by graphene oxide [88]. The preparation process is schematically illustrated in Fig. 6 (a). The MOF-derived particles are wrapped by wrinkled graphene, and the MnO nanoparticles are approximately 5–10 nm in size, and are demonstrated by the characteristic lattice fringes (Fig. 6b and c). The MnO@NC-G battery can achieve a narrow voltage gap of 0.88 V and a maximum discharge capacity of 25021 mA h g−1 within 2.0–4.5 V at 50 mA g−1. Impressively, a MnO@NC-G cathode that cycled for 206 cycles at 1 A g−1 was retrieved and reassembled with a fresh Li foil anode and electrolyte, and the refurbished MnO@NC-G battery can be durably cycled for another 176 cycles. The authors attribute this electrochemical performance to the following advantages: highly dispersed MnO nanoparticles provides accessible catalytic sites; interconnected 2D graphene nanosheet-nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks can accelerate electron transportation; and the robust MnO@NC-G cathode possess a wide range of pores, which guarantee the mass transfer and cathode’s stability in repeated battery cycling process. Rho et al. atomically dispersed IrO x /Ir bi-phase particles as single-atom catalysts (SACs) on nitrogen-doped CNTs for catalyzing the CO2RR/CO2ER (Fig. 6d) [197]. They found that the size of the IrO x /Ir SACs can be minimized to an atomic scale of 4 Å. The IrO x /Ir SACs, with their low coordination number and surface oxygen density, enable facile adsorption of Li+ and CO2 reactants, which consequently enhances their catalytic activity for the CO2RR. They found that the charge transfer resistance at the electrochemical interface can be reduced as the particle downsized to a single-atom unit. Xu et al. used a layered cobalt-titanium layered double oxide (LDO) to disperse RuO2 as single atoms by interlayered stereoconfinement [210]. RuIII anions were intercalated into the interlayers of LDO, which were then calcinated at 500 °C in air to form the RuO2/LDO (Fig. 6e). The RuO2/LDO nanoflakes exhibit a hierarchically porous structure composed of mesopores and macropores (Fig. 6f), which offers accessible pore channels for gas diffusion and ion transportation, thus feeding the active sites with sufficient reactants. As shown in Fig. 6(g), the RuO2/LDO battery shows a low charge overpotential of ∼0.4 V at 166 mA g−1. Ma et al. prepared porous Mn2O3 through a low-cost sol-gel method combined with a pyrolysis process [204]. The porous Mn2O3 (P-Mn2O3) exhibits a typical bi-continuous structure (Fig. 6h), which offers abundant channels for mass transfer, ample space for accommodation of discharge products, and large surface area for construction of multiphase reaction interfaces. Thanks to the porosity and superior catalytic activity, the battery configured with P-Mn2O3 catalyst presented a lower voltage gap of 1.4 V for the second cycle (Fig. 6i) and can be durably cycled for over 50 cycles (namely 2000 h) at 50 mA g−1. The authors found that the C product species are featured with high graphitization and can be reversibly co-decomposed with Li2CO3 during the charging process. Zhang et al. reported a composite of NiO nanoplates evenly dispersed on CNTs as schematically illustrated in Fig. 6(j) [19]. The N2 adsorption-desorption curve shows that the NiO-CNT composite has abundant pores range from 20 to 100 nm and a high specific surface area of up to 118.6 m2 g−1 (Fig. 6k). Lu et al. prepared porous NiO nanofibers (NiO NFs) by using electrospinning technique followed by a thermolysis process [211]. The TEM image in Fig. 6(l) shows that the NiO NFs are composed of numerous nanoparticles with typical size of ∼30 nm and contain nanopores that are tens of nanometers in size. The large specific surface area and abundant pores provided by the porous structure facilitate the contact between discharge products and electrodes, promote the exposure of active sites, facilitate the deposition of discharge products, and accelerate the transmission of electrons and reactants. Defect engineering has been recognized to have important impacts on improving the performance of electrocatalysts through tuning the electronic states and creating active sites [193,215–218]. The importance of defect engineering for catalyzing has been extensively highlighted in various catalytic fields such as the hydrogen reduction reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [107,215,219–223]. For years, defective oxides such as MnO2, NiO, and CeO2, which possess excellent physicochemical properties (e.g., electronic structure, band level, electronic conductivity), have attracted widespread attention among researchers [87,93,217]. Chen et al. prepared a Ni, Fe co-doped δ-MnO2 (Ni-Fe-δ-MnO2) nanoflowers by in situ etching a Ni-Fe Prussian blue analog via a sacrificing-template strategy as shown in Fig. 7 (a) [93]. The Mn 2p XPS spectra depicted signals of Mn3+ besides Mn4+ from MnO2, which is originated from the Mn4+ transformation with the formation of oxygen defects (Fig. 7b). The Ni-Fe-δ-MnO2 shows the highest oxygen vacancy ratio as compared with δ-MnO2 and the precursor of Ni-Fe-δ-MnO2, suggesting abundant defects have been created in its structure (Fig. 7c). The high oxygen vacancy density of Ni-Fe-δ-MnO2 is further proved by its higher EPR signals (Fig. 7d). The Ni 2p and Fe 2p peaks of Ni-Fe-δ-MnO2 both show negatively shift relative to its precursor, which is attributable to the coordination between the dopants and O, thereby increase the surrounding electron cloud density, eventually inhibiting Jahn-Teller distortion, stabilize the MnO2 structure, and maximize the catalytic active sites for CO2RR and CO2ER. Ge et al. loaded a Co-doped alpha-MnO2 nanowire onto a piece of carbon cloth (CC) through a simple hydrothermal reaction, and utilized the as-prepared Co0.2Mn0.8O2/CC as cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries [201]. The electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) profile of Co0.2Mn0.8O2 depicts several weak signals at 13.2, 27.2, and 65.7 eV, suggesting the incorporation of Co atoms into the lattice of MnO2 (Fig. 7e). The Co0.2Mn0.8O2/CC battery delivers a high capacity of 8160 mA h g−1, a low voltage gap of ∼ 0.73 V, and a high cycle durability for over 500 cycles at 100 mA g−1 (Fig. 7f). The author attributed this excellent performance to the Co-interstitial doping and phase morphology of the Co0.2Mn0.8O2/CC electrode. The DOS mappings in Fig. 7(g and h) reveal that the Co-interstitial site can lower the bandgap of alpha-MnO2 to form an impurity band, which bestowed on Co0.2Mn0.8O2 a small bandgap and high conductivity. The Co0.2Mn0.8O2 is featured with abundant pores and a high specific surface area, which contribute to achieving decent mass transfer. Zheng et al. prepared oxygen vacancy-rich NiO nanosheets on carbon cloth (NiO-Vo@CC) by treating NiO@CC in a NaBH4 solution (Fig. 7i) [214]. The NiO-Vo@CC shows a distinct electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) signal with g value of 1.99, indicating the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies within the NiO-Vo@CC (Fig. 7j). The discharge and charge overpotential of the NiO-Vo@CC battery are both lowered as compared with those of the NiO@CC battery, indicating the oxygen vacancy can accelerate both CO2RR and CO2ER kinetics. The electron delocalization induced by the defects of NiO-Vo make Lewis base surface, which is inclined to donate electrons to CO2 and benefit CO2 activation. Thanks to the well-engineered oxygen vacancies, the edge-rich NiO-Vo can adsorb more CO2 and thus offers the advantage for the subsequent electrochemical reaction. Deng et al. prepared 2D Co-doped CeO2 nanosheets (CC), which was then anchored on graphene aerogel (GA) to achieve a binder-free cathode catalyst with abundant pore channels for mass transfer [87]. As revealed by the PDOS mappings of CeO2 and Co-doped CeO2, the Co dopant can decrease the bandgap and thereby enhance the conductivity of Co-doped CeO2 (Fig. 7k and l). DFT calculations have shown that Ce atoms with increased electron density exhibit a high capability for CO2 adsorption. The CO2 adsorption energy of CeO2(110) is −0.015 eV, whereas this value is reduced to −0.098 eV for Co-doped CeO2(110), indicating that the Co dopant aids in enhancing the CO2 capture capability. Moreover, when a CO2 molecule is adsorbed on Co-doped CeO2(110), the C = O bond length can be shortened from 1.175 Å to 1.290 Å, thereby facilitating the rupture of this covalent bond and promoting the activation as well as the subsequent reduction of CO2. Generally, the incorporation of a foreign component can lead to distortions in chemical bonding, alterations in charge distribution, as well as the introduction of compressive or tensile strains across the heterointerface [33,84,85,98,103,134,207,208]. The heterostructure electrocatalysts engineered by hybridizing two or more components/phases have been considered a promising option for Li-CO2 batteries owing to their synergy and unique electronic structure [8,15,54,225,226]. Moreover, the interface engineering strategy has been firmly established as a promising optimization methodology for the development of high-efficiency electrocatalysts due to its diverse realization avenues, a wide range of applications, diversified operation mechanisms, and remarkable electrocatalytic performance [98,148,208,224–227]. Liu et al. synthesized sea urchinlike Mn2O3-Mn3O4 microspheres through an ammonia-assisted reduction strategy and revealed the dual-phase synergy mechanism in Mn2O3-Mn3O4 catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries (Fig. 8 a) [224]. The Mn2O3-Mn3O4 nanocomposite is featured with porosity with numerous nanopores size around 20 nm and its outer nanoribbons are composed of nanoparticles of about 25 nm. Both CO2 temperature-programmed desorption test and DFT theoretical calculation results show that Mn3O4 had the stronger CO2 adsorption ability than Mn2O3 (Fig. 8b). The adsorption energy of the intermediate CO3* of CO2RR is higher on the surface of Mn2O3 than on the surface of Mn3O4 (Fig. 8c). In this regard, Li2CO3 is more likely to regularly nucleate on the surface of Mn2O3 and thus improves the kinetics of the CO2ER. By coupling the dual-phase synergy and unique structure, the Mn2O3-Mn3O4 presented a high discharge capacity of 19024 mA h g−1, a low voltage gap of 1.24 V, and long lifespan of 1380 h at 100 mA g−1. Liu et al. prepared a composite of porous zinc cobalt oxide spinel nanorods and carbon nanotubes (ZnCo2O4@CNTs), which exhibited superior electrochemical performance than its single-phase counterparts and the referential Co3O4@CNTs in Li-CO2 batteries [202]. The porous nanorod structure is demonstrated by TEM image in Fig. 8(d). The ZnCo2O4@CNT battery exhibits a high cycling stability for over 200 cycles with a steady charge voltage of ∼4.3 V at 100 mA g−1 when the cutoff capacity was fixed to 500 mA h g−1 (Fig. 8e). The authors attributed the superior performance of ZnCo2O4@CNTs to the synergistic effects: The porous structure of ZnCo2O4 nanorod and the 3D network of the CNTs can only boost both electron and mass transfer, but also provide free space for accommodation of discharge products; The hybridization of ZnCo2O4 and CNTs forms abundant reactive sites for CO2 diffusion and evolution. Ma et al. prepared a spongy electrocatalyst composed of RuAl and Cu2O (MP-Cu2O/RuAl) by carving out of a RuCuAl ternary alloy through a chemical dealloying process [7]. The electron micrographs and N2 adsorption/desorption measurement demonstrate the trimodal porous feature of the MP-Cu2O/RuAl. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) patterns show that the MP-Cu2O/RuAl is a polycrystalline Cu2O/RuAl heterojunction aggregation. XPS spectra present red-shifts for both Cu0/Cu1+ and Ru0 as well as a blue-shift for Al0, stating the strong electronic interaction between Cu2O and RuAl. They performed DFT calculations to understand the working mechanism of Cu2O/RuAl heterojunction on the CO2RR/CO2ER in Li-CO2 batteries. The Cu2O(100)/RuAl(011) presents relatively higher adsorption than Cu2O(100) for both CO2 and Li2CO3/C, thus benefiting the CO2 activation and reduction as well as the uniform deposition of discharge products (Fig. 8f). Moreover, as shown in Fig. 8(g), Cu2O(100)/RuAl(011) can effectively lower the Gibbs energy change of the rate-limiting Li–O bond dissociation of the in Li2CO3, thereby improving the kinetics and reversibility of Li-CO2 batteries. Recently, light assistance has emerged as an intriguing and promising strategy to enhance the round-trip and energy efficiencies of Li-CO2 batteries [46,48,92,94,228]. By directly harnessing sunlight, it aids the electrochemical conversion of CO2, thereby transitioning the process from electrochemical to either a combined electrochemical-photochemical or a photo-assisted electrochemical energy conversion [229]. In this case, light-assisted Li-CO2 batteries utilize semiconductor materials as cathode catalysts, which generally lack intrinsic catalytic capability and photoelectrochemical conversion reversibility for CO2RR/CO2ER, resulting in inferior energy efficiency and cycling stability [230]. Zhu et al. reported a Fe2O3/Cu2O type-II heterojunction as photocathode for light-assisted Li-CO2 batteries [48]. Numerous Fe2O3 nanograins size from 10 to 20 nm are anchored on the surface of Cu2O nanowires (Fig. 8h), and the HRTEM images in Fig. 8(i) proves the existence of Fe2O3/Cu2O heterointerface. The Cu 2p XPS peaks show slight negative-shift, implying the Fe2O3 nanograins ten to donate electrons to Cu2O across the nano-heterointerface. The light-assisted Fe2O3/Cu2O battery delivers a low voltage polarization of 0.19 V at 0.01 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8j) and can be durably cycled for 260 cycles with a coulombic efficiency of 87.8% at 0.1 mA cm−2 under full-sunlight irradiation (AM 1.5 G). Generally, there are two main pathways for the nucleation and growth of discharge products, namely catalyst surface pathway and solution phase pathway [86,134,231–233]. The catalyst surface pathway usually results in uniform film-like deposition morphology of the discharge products thanks to the adsorption and guidance of the cathode catalyst [86]. In contrast, the discharge products on the catalyst through a solution phase pathway are usually islanding particles [231]. And the uniform deposition of discharge products is commonly preferred as they are easily decomposed during the charging process. Ma et al. prepared a MnOOH arrays adhered on stainless-steel mesh (MnOOH/SS) by using a PVP-assisted hydrothermal method (Fig. 9 a) [86]. They found C–OH bond on the O 1s XPS spectrum of discharged MnOOH/SS cathode and reasonably attributed this signal to the coupling of OH in MnOOH with the C atoms of carbonaceous species during the nucleation process of C (Fig. 9b). Moreover, the Mn 2p 3/2 and Mn 2p 1/2 peaks both present a red shift after discharging, which might be originated from the electron donation of the C–OH bond (Fig. 9c). These results suggest that the MnOOH possess a good interaction with the discharge (intermediate) products during CO2RR, thereby modulate the nucleation and growth of C. The spontaneous reaction process between CO2 and Li was simulated by ab initio molecular dynamics simulation (AIMD). Fig. 9(d) confirmed the formation of both the intermediate (LiCO2 and LiCO) and Li2CO3 upon the AIMD simulation. The Mayer bond orders of Li–O natural bond orbital of Li2CO3 is distinctly lower than that of LiCO. The charge density difference diagrams depict that the MnOOH has a lower CO2 adsorption, while the Li–O formed between the Li in Li2CO3 and the O in MnOOH has a high adsorption energy of −4.31 eV (Fig. 9e). The adsorbed Li2CO3 and C can act as the seeds to guide their subsequent deposition to form a uniform film. As a result, the discharge products show a uniform deposition on the surface of the catalyst without any obvious aggregation. The metal (oxy)hydroxides can adsorb and guide the growth of discharge products, thereby achieve high efficiency in both CO2RR and CO2ER [8,12,174]. However, these compounds generally show poor electronic conductivity and inferior intrinsic catalytic activity [86,234,235]. Therefore, it is a facile but effective strategy to hybrid the metal (oxy)hydroxides with a foreign component with high catalytic activity and decent mass and electron transportation ability. Jian et al. crosslinked two-dimensional (2D) CoAl-LDH nanosheets with 3D MP-RuCoAl alloy (MP-RuCoAl alloy⊥CoAl-LDH) via one-step dealloying of Al-Co-Ru alloy precursor as depicted in Fig. 9(f) [8]. The SEM and TEM images show that the CoAl-LDH nanosheets are interconnected with each other and tightly immobilized on multilevel nanoporous MP-RuCoAl alloy substrate (Fig. 9g and h). The MP-RuCoAl alloy⊥CoAl-LDH shows weak-crystallinity feature. HRTEM image depicts that the MP-RuCoAl alloy is mainly composed of nanograins with zigzagged interface, thus producing abundant nano-interface. Fast Fourier transform (FFT) and inverse FFT (IFFT) techniques further demonstrate the existence of the Ru0.8Co0.2/RuAl and RuAl/Ru heterojunctions. Benefiting from the large surface area, interconnected pore channels, abundant heterointerface, and improved conductivity, the MPRuCoAl⊥CoAl-LDH shows enhanced electrocatalytic performances relative to the CoAl-LDH. Wang et al. prepared a microbial-derived functional carbon (M-FC) decorated hollow NiCo-LDHs nanoflower (M-FC/NiCo-LDHs) as cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries (Fig. 9i) [12]. SEM demonstrated that the surface of the discharged M-FC/NiCo-LDHs electrode is covered with layer structured discharge products (Fig. 9m), which almost disappeared upon charging. The morphology evolution of the discharge products on the M-FC/NiCo-LDHs electrode is studied as presented in Fig. 9(j–m). The M-FC/NiCo-LDHs electrode basically maintains its pristine sheetlike morphology when the discharge depth was limited to less than 5000 mA h g−1, and shows flower-like products composed of numerous nanosheets when the discharge capacity was increased to 9000 mA h g−1. They considered the petal-like morphology of the discharge products is inherit from the NiCo-LDHs nanoflower, which guide the growth of Li2CO3 and C alongside the base face of the sheet-like catalyst. The size of the petal-like discharge products grew in horizontal dimension as the deepen of the discharge depth and finally reached to ∼600 nm. They highlight the ordered growth of discharge products is beneficial to achieve fluent gas/ion diffusion and maximize the area for cathodic reactions. 4.2 Metal sulfides Recently, metal sulfides have emerged as promising cathode catalysts for Li-CO2 batteries [40,142,236–238]. By hybridizing metal sulfides to create a heterointerface, the interfacial electron interaction prompts charge redistribution across the interface, yielding electron-rich substrates that enhance the adsorption of electron-deficient C atoms from CO2 [15,84,85,239,240]. Moreover, as stated in section 4.1, the controlled morphology is beneficial for achieving enhanced catalytic performance of metal oxides, and it has been demonstrated to be effective for metal sulfides as well [142,238]. Wang et al. loaded ZnS quantum dots onto nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (ZnS QDs/N-rGO) via a common solvothermal method [15]. The TEM image in Fig. 10 (a) depicts that ZnS QDs are mainly size in the range of 1.5–3 nm and are randomly but uniformly adhered to the N-rGO. DFT calculation is performed to study the interfacial charge density. Thanks to the strong interfacial polarization, the electrons migrate from N-rGO to ZnS QDs, thus result in electrons (yellow) and holes (blue) gather at ZnS QDs and N-rGO, respectively, arousing internal electronic field (Fig. 10b). The interfacial charge distribution is schematically illustrated in Fig. 10(c). The charge enrichment at ZnS QDs improves the catalytic activities for CO2RR, while the gather of hole at N-rGO can accelerate the kinetics of CO2ER. The strong interfacial electronic interaction of ZnS QDs/N-rGO can facilitate the nucleation of discharge products and thus achieve a thin Li2CO3/C film, which is inclined to be decomposed at lower charge voltage and thus result in high cyclability and energy efficiency of the battery. A hollow NiS2/FeS2 nanostructures dispersed on N, S co-doped graphene aerogel (NiS2/FeS2-NSGA) was designed and utilized as the cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries by Jin et al. (Fig. 10d) [85]. The NiS2/FeS2-NSGA efficiently accelerates the kinetics of Li2CO3 decomposition, lowers the discharge-charge voltage gap to 1.10 V at 100 mA g−1, and can be durably operated for more than 127 cycles at 1 A g−1 with a cutoff capacity of 500 mA h g−1. XPS and DFT calculation were conducted to clarify the origin of the decent electrochemical performance. The XPS core-levels of Ni 2p and Fe 2p spectra of NiS2/FeS2-NSGA respectively show red- and blue-shift by comparing with the corresponding monometallic sulfides, indicating the electron migration from FeS2 to NiS2 (Fig. 10e and f). The charge density difference image in Fig. 10(g) visually shows the above charge redistribution across the NiS2/FeS2 interface, which inducing the upward shift of the d-band center and thereby enables the NiS2/FeS2 effective catalytic site for prompting the CO2 electrochemical recycling reactions. Moreover, the authors considered the synergistic effect between the NiS2/FeS2 heterojunction and the NSGA substrate as another factor to further improve battery performance. Lu et al. tried to achieve more accessible catalytic sites for both CO2RR and CO2ER by vertically anchoring MoS2 nanosheets on the surface of Co9S8 sheets supported by carbon paper (V-MoS2/Co9S8@CP) [84]. The V-MoS2/Co9S8 heterojunction with an interface along the edge is schematically illustrated in Fig. 10(h). The V-MoS2/Co9S8@CP batteries show superior performance compared with those configured with the catalysts of horizontally growing MoS2 on Co9S8 (H-MoS2/Co9S8@CP) and corresponding monometallic sulfides (MoS2@CP and Co9S8@CP). Compared with Co9S8@CP, the Co2+ and Co3+ in V-MoS2/Co9S8@CP are positively shifted, while the Mo4+ in MoS2/Co9S8@CP is negatively shifted relative to MoS2@CP. DFT calculations show that the fully exposed MoS2 edge shows stronger adsorption for both CO2 and Li (Fig. 10i), thus accelerates the kinetics of CO2RR. As possible reaction paths for the CO2RR were divided into two stages as shown in Fig. 10(j). The Co9S8 shows the smallest Gibbs free energy change (ΔGf(r)) in the first stage, while the MoS2 edge exhibits the smallest ΔGf(r) value in the second stage. Consequently, the MoS2/Co9S8@CP can achieve relatively lower energy barrier for the rate-determining steps of CO2RR owing to the synergy of Co9S8 and the fully exposed MoS2 edges. For the CO2ER, the rupture of Li–O bond is considered the key for the decomposition of Li2CO3. The MoS2 basal plane adsorbed Li2CO3 by forming Li–S bonds, while MoS2 edges and Co9S8 through both Li–S and metal (Mo or Co)-O bonds. Therefore, the MoS2/Co9S8@CP can effectively weaken the Li–O bond and thus promote the decomposition of Li2CO3. Chen et al. used DFT calculations to guide the design of metal sulfide catalyst [83]. They found that the nucleophilic N dopants in MS2 (M = Mo, W, Re) tend to adsorb Li, while the electrophilic S vacancies show advantage in C or O adsorption. Moreover, the Li–O bond in Li2CO3 adsorbed on MS2 planes can be weakened by the formation of Li–S bonds, and the MS2, 1SV-MS2 (MS2 with S vacancy), and 1 N-MS2 (MS2 with N dopant) substrates exhibit sequential enhancement in the rupture of the Li–O bond. Hence, the authors engineered electrophilic S vacancies and nucleophilic N dopants as dual active sites within the MS2 plane (NSV-MS2), aiming to tailor the CO2RR and CO2ER activities in Li-CO2 batteries as illustrated in Fig. 10(k). As a result, as shown in Fig. 10(l and m), a NSV-ReS2/CP with a N/S ratio of 5 shows a small voltage polarization of 0.66 V and a high energy efficiency of 81.1% at 20 μA cm−2. 4.3 Metal nitrides and phosphides Carbon-supported and nitrogen-coordinated single metal catalysts are usually named as M-N-C, which have exhibited excellent activity and selectivity for the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to CO in aqueous solution [13,81,241–243]. It is also demonstrated an effective catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries [242]. The M-N-C catalysts generally contain abundant “MN x ” moieties consist M atoms bonded with pyridinic N sites [243]. The M atoms tend to donate electrons to the pyridinic N, thus result in high positive charge in the M atoms, which is considered the active centers for catalyzing the CO2RR/CO2ER in Li-CO2 batteries [241]. Hu et al. incorporated FeN x into a 3D interconnected porous N,S-codoped holey graphene architecture (Fe-ISA/N,S-HG) as schematically illustrated in Fig. 11 (a) [13]. They performed DFT calculations to clarify the electronic structures of various sites in the Fe-ISA/N,S-HG by comparing the charge density of N-doped graphene, S-doped graphene, N,S-codoped graphene, Fe/N-doped graphene with the FeN4 moieties in the center and at the edge of the graphene sheet. Among them, the N-doped graphene and S-doped graphene show negligible spin density distribution on their skeleton, while the N,S-codoped graphene shows an obvious spin re-distribution. Based on this, they suggest that the superior catalytic performance arises from the combined effects stemming from the charge and spin redistribution, facilitated by N,S-codoping, along with the implantation of FeN4 moieties embedded within the carbon framework. This synergy promotes efficient charge transfer between carbon atoms and heteroatoms in the Fe-ISA/N,S-HG, enabling the effective catalysis of CO2RR/CO2ER. Interestingly, small product particles with a diameter of 2–10 nm generated on the Fe-ISA/N,S-HG electrode upon discharging (Fig. 11b). Distinct from the sizable Li2CO3 nanoparticles (exceeding 50 nm) observed on previously reported catalysts or the N,S-codoped HG (approximately 20 nm), the small particles present on the Fe-ISA/N,S-HG electrode are easier to be decomposed during charging, contributing to a lowered charge overpotential, decent reversibility, and admirable cyclability. Ding et al. prepared a Fe-N-C catalyst with abundant Fe-N x active sites and micropores by pyrolysis of a MOF [242]. The abundant micropores and single Fe atoms within the framework promote the CO2 diffusion, the electrolyte penetration, and the atomic dispersion of the highly active Fe-N x sites in the Fe-N-C catalyst. The large amount of Fe-N x sites can achieve rapid and massive nucleation of Li2CO3/C, contributing to form small and dense discharge products, thereby accelerate the kinetics for both CO2RR and CO2ER. The Fe-N-C batteries delivered a high cyclability for over 140 times with a limited capacity of 500 mA h g−1 and a large discharge capacity of 13238 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1. The feasibility and universality of pyrolysis of MOF precursor for fabrication of metal nitride catalysts has been demonstrated and highlighted by various research groups [81,104,241,242]. Similar to the Fe-N x , some other metal-N coordinated active sites have also been demonstrated effective in Li-CO2 batteries [81,241]. Single-atom cadmium with a Cd-N4 moiety immobilized on nitrogen-doped carbon (Cd SAs/NC) is proposed by Zhu et al. and is schematically depicted in Fig. 11(c) [241]. They performed DFT calculations to clarify the efficacy of Cd SAs in facilitating both the CO2RR and CO2ER in Li-CO2 batteries. For the thermodynamically limiting step in CO2RR, namely transforming the *CO and CO2 to *CO3 and *C, the Gibbs free energy change on Cd SAs/NC is obviously lower than those on N with different chemical environment in NC. Moreover, with the aid of Cd SAs, the Cd SAs/NC composite significantly reduces the energy barrier for the decomposition of Li2CO3, as compared to NC (Fig. 11d). The Cd SAs/NC batteries exhibit a low voltage gap of approximately 1.74 V at 2 A g−1, and can be steadily cycled for over 1680 and 660 cycles with a cut-off capacity of 500 and 1000 mA h g−1, respectively, at 1 A g−1. Lin et al. developed a Ru atomic cluster (RuAC) and single-atom Ru-N4 (RuSA) composite sites on N-doped carbon nanobox substrate (RuAC+SA@NCB) a complex of Ru3+/NH2-carbon quantum dots and NCB matrix (Fig. 11e) [81]. The RuAC+SA@NCB exhibits superior catalytic activity toward the CO2 electrochemical recycling reactions and achieves lower voltage gaps of 1.65 and 1.86 V at 1 and 2 A g−1, respectively. They calculate the Gibbs free energies for all intermediate steps of the CO2ER and CO2RR (Fig. 11f). The RuSA side shows lower energy barriers than the RuAC side in most of the intermediate steps of the CO2RR, indicating that the Ru-N4 should be the active site in the RuAC+SA@NCB catalyst. Moreover, the authors highlight and demonstrate the electronic synergy between RuAC and Ru-N4, which improves the electrocatalytic activity toward the CO2ER and CO2RR. The Ru-N4 site in RuAC+SA@NCB exhibits the lowest energy barrier for the rate-determining carbon-desorption step in the CO2RR. Moreover, for the CO2ER, the breaking of Li–O bonds in the *Li2C2O4 is considered the rate-determining step. *Li2C2O4 adsorbed on the RuAC+SA exhibits a relatively longer Li–O bond compared with that adsorbed on the RuSA, making the Li2C2O4 dissociation easier on the RuAC+SA with enhanced kinetics for the CO2ER. A carbon-free, freestanding vanadium nitride nanowire (VN-NW) membrane is prepared by Pipes et al. through the high-temperature nitridation of a V2O5-NW precursor [82]. Electronic microscopic images in Fig. 12 (a and b) depict that the VN-NW evenly distributed on the membrane, and the typical diameters and lengths of the nanowires are 50–200 nm and tens of microns, respectively. The nanowires are composed of irregular VN nanoparticles sized from several to dozens of nanometers. Impressively, the VN-NW batteries achieve higher capacity, longer cycling stability, and better rate capability than those configured with control cathode catalyst made from multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) although the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface area of MWCNT is several times larger than that of VN-NW (Fig. 12c). This result indicates that the catalytic activity of VN-NW is significantly higher than that of MWCNT. A binder-free MoN nanofibers anchored on carbon cloth (CC) (CC@MoN NFs) was engineered by Qi et al. and utilized as freestanding cathode catalyst for the assembly of flexible belt-shaped Li-CO2 battery as depicted in Fig. 12(d) [106]. They found that the CC@MoN NFs can stabilize the 2-electron reaction intermediate Li2C2O4 by forming Mo–O coupling bridge with the low-valence Mo atoms in MoN. DFT calculations show that the MoN(200) surface has high adsorption energy for both Li and CO2, thus can feeding the CO2RR with adequate reactants. The charge density difference images in Fig. 12(e and f) demonstrate that the MoN(200) has stronger adsorption for Li2C2O4 rather than Li2CO3.
