The Mo 3d XPS spectra demonstrates the increment and decrement of Mo6+/Mo3+ ratio of the discharged and charged CC@MoN NFs compared with the pristine one. The Li 1s and C 1s spectra of discharged CC@MoN NFs respectively show peaks at 55.6 and 288.6 eV, and both them almost disappear after recharging, suggesting the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2C2O4 (Fig. 12g and h). The flexible belt-shaped CC@MoN NFs battery can operate under different bending angles or twisting states, and achieve a low charge voltage plateau of ∼3.19 V, a high initial energy efficiency for over 88%, and a long lifespan for over 86 cycles. Guo et al. dispersed RuP2 nanoparticles on N, P dual-doped carbon films (RuP2-NPCF) through pyrolysis of a mixture of phytic acid (PA)-crosslinked ruthenium complexes and melamine (Fig. 13 a) [20]. The diffraction peaks in Fig. 13(b) demonstrated the existence of RuP2 phase in the RuP2-NPCF catalyst. The formation of RuP2 and the successful P and N doping into the carbon framework were confirmed by XPS (Fig. 13c). The RuP2-NPCF is a typical porous film with a high BET surface area of 392 m2 g−1. The porous structure of the RuP2-NPCF was demonstrated by the SEM image in Fig. 13(d). Tremendous RuP2 nanocrystals are densely and uniformly distributed on the NPCF as depicted by the TEM images in Fig. 13(e). The synergy between the RuP2 NPs and NPCF bestowed high catalytic activity and durability on the RuP2-NPCF, thus decreased charge voltage for Li2CO3 decomposition, while the porous structure with a high surface area maximized the exposure of catalytic sites and improved the mass transfer. To modulate the electronic structure, Qu et al. incorporate O into the lattice of CoP (O-CoP) nanosheets by high-temperature phosphorylation of Co(OH)2 (Fig. 13f) [80]. The O-CoP exhibits a morphology characterized by 2D nanosheets, possessing a thickness of ∼25 nm (Fig. 13g). The O dopant makes the density of states of the catalytic active surface at the Fermi level become relaxed, thus strengthen the adsorption of reactants and promote the CO2RR. The charge density difference depicts an electron cloud transfer from Co to O atom in the P–Co–O bond (Fig. 13h), which is beneficial for the adsorption and destruction of CO2 on the interface of O–CoP. Mott-Schottky heterojunctions, which are formed by coupling semiconductors and metals, have been widely studied in various fields such as Li-S and Zn-air batteries owing to their unique interfacial electronic structure [244,245]. The interfacial electron redistribution can induce charge separation and change internal electric fields of the interface, which is beneficial for the ion and electron transportation, thereby adjusting the reaction pathways and enhancing catalytic activity of the CO2 electrochemical recycling reactions [102,246]. Wu et al. prepared a porous Mo3P/Mo Mott-Schottky heterojunction via a phosphating reaction of a MoO3 precursor [102]. The Mo 3d XPS spectra of Mo3P/Mo indicate that the peak intensities of low-valence Mo species decrease during discharging and recovered upon charging. The unpaired electrons in the outer shell of low-valence Mo are inclined to transfer to the O atoms in the discharge products, thereby stabilizing Li2C2O4 during discharging. The C 1s sub-peak located at 289.0 eV further proves the existence of Li2C2O4 on the discharged Mo3P/Mo catalyst. In situ DEMS test indicates that the ratio of the total transferred electron number to the consumption of CO2 is roughly 1, suggesting the battery reaction operates based on a 2-electron pathway at a current density of 100 mA g−1 (Fig. 13i). Moreover, in situ FTIR demonstrates that the Mo3P/Mo catalyst can stabilize the discharge product as Li2C2O4 at a relatively low current density of 50 mA g−1 (Fig. 13j), but achieves Li2CO3 product at a much higher current density of 400 mA g−1 (Fig. 13k). 4.4 Metal carbides and borides Transition metal carbides (TMCs) have been widely accepted as promising catalysts owing to their eminent thermal stability, corrosion resistance, cost-effectiveness, chemical stability, and Pt-like catalytic activity [43,247–249]. The coupling of C and TM atoms endows TMCs with heightened d-band electron density at the Fermi level, conferring upon them unique catalytic activity [78]. More importantly, some of these metal carbides have been demonstrated to be effective catalysts for stabilizing the intermediate Li2C2O4 as the final product [22,50,107,108]. In 2017, Hou et al. prepared Mo2C/CNT via a carbothermal reduction process and introduced it as cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries [22]. Impressively, they found that the Mo2C could stabilize the amorphous discharge intermediate product Li2C2O4 by coupling Mo in Mo2C with O in C2O4 2− through coordinative charge transfer (Fig. 14 a). In this case, the formation of insulating Li2CO3 is avoid and the CO2ER can thus be easily conducted by uncoupling of the Mo–O bond in the amorphous discharge product Li2C2O4-Mo2C, which lowers the charge voltage to <3.5 V (Fig. 14b). A similar report on that the Li2C2O4 can be stabilized by Mo2C was reported by Zhou et al [79]. They prepared a freestanding hybrid film by anchoring Mo2C nanoparticles on CNT cloth (denoted as CC@Mo2C NPs) as cathode catalyst for quasi-solid-state flexible fiber-shaped Li-CO2 battery. The working mechanism of Mo2C in the battery is proposed as follows. The CO2 is initially reduced to C2O4 2− which then bonded with the delocalized electrons originated from low-valent Mo atoms (Mo2+ and Mo3+) by forming Mo–O bond with Mo2C. The charge density difference shows that the outer electrons of the electron-donor Mo2C have transferred into O atoms in the electron-acceptor Li2C2O4 in the optimized adsorption configuration, thus stabilizing the Li2C2O4 as the final discharge product by delocalized electrons. The Mo–O bond is broken and the delocalized electrons returned to Mo atoms during the subsequent charging process as demonstrated by in situ Raman and XPS. The Mo–O bond and Li2C2O4 related Raman signals increased/decreased gradually as the discharge/charge proceeded. Meanwhile, the Mo2+ and Mo3+ are oxidized to high-valent Mo during discharging and are reduced back to lower valence states during the subsequent charging. Moreover, the author further confirmed that the product should be lithium oxalate by utilizing a special precipitation method based on the acidity difference between Li2C2O4 and H3PO4. Yang and co-workers systematically investigated the Gibbs free energy changes of different intermediates during the nucleation processes of Li2C2O4 and Li2CO3 on Mo2C by using first-principles DFT calculations (Fig. 14c) [109]. They found that the (001) and (101) planes of β-Mo2C exhibit the lowest discharge and charge overpotentials, respectively. The Mo2C can increase the free energy change associated with the disproportionation of Li2C2O4 to Li2CO3, thereby transforming Li2C2O4 from an “intermediate product” to a “final product”. Interestingly, Zhu et al. found that the discharge products generated on another molybdenum carbide MoC is Li2CO3, rather than Li2C2O4 observed on Mo2C [77]. They prepared a composite nanofiber (NCMC) cathode catalyst by coating a N-rich carbon shell embedded with MoC nanoparticles onto multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) through hydrothermal reaction followed by a subsequent pyrolysis process. The Raman spectra present the appearance/disappearance of two bands at about 1089 and 94 cm−1, indicating the reversible formation/decomposition of carbonate species during discharging/charging process (Fig. 14d). The C 1s XPS spectrum of discharged NCMC electrode depicts a peak at ∼289.5 eV, which is attributable to the O=C–O group of CO3 2− (Fig. 14e and f). Moreover, they performed DFT calculations to clarify the adsorption of CO2 and Li2CO3 on NCMC and N-free carbon embedded with MoC nanoparticles-MWCNT core-shell material (CMC). The NCMC exhibits much stronger adsorption for both CO2 and Li2CO3 than CMC. The NCMC is considered a Mott-Schottky-type catalyst and the MoC donate electrons to N-rich carbon to achieve the same Fermi levels. The charge redistribution across the heterointerface can promote the adsorption and activation of CO2 as well as lower the energy barrier for Li2CO3 decomposition. The spatial configuration of carbonate is a stable triangle composed of one C atom and three O atoms [78,83,176,245,250,251]. Zhang et al. reported that the electron-rich W in W2C can bond with O in the CO3 2−, thereby revolutionize the electron distribution and destabilize the triangle structure of carbonate [78]. They prepared the pure phase W2C by a two-step carburization method illustrate in Fig. 14(g). DFT calculations show that the adsorption energy of Li2CO3 on W2C(101) is 4.03 eV, which is obviously higher than that on CNTs (0.52 eV). Charge density difference image in Fig. 14(h) shows that there is obvious electron interaction between the O of Li2CO3 and the W of W2C (101). Moreover, the electrons accumulated at Li–O bond are partially transferred to Li–C bond. Partial density of states (PDOS) of the W2C (101)-Li2CO3 adsorption configuration shows that the p orbital of O atoms is combined with the s, d orbital of W atoms below the Fermi level, suggesting the existence of W–O bond. The decomposition barrier of Li2CO3 on W2C (101) is calculated to 0.69 eV, which is obviously lower than that on the CNTs surface (2.91 eV). 2D transition metal borides, known as MBenes, have aroused wide attention in diverse electrocatalytic reactions owing to their metallic nature, accessible active sites, and admirable electronic conductivity [11,252,253]. Mir et al. studied the CO2 capture and activation on MBenes (M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, and Fe) by using DFT calculations [252]. They found that the Sc2B2 and Fe2B2 show the highest and lowest CO2 adsorption energy, respectively. And the CO2 adsorption energy on Ti2B2, V2B2, Cr2B2, and Mn2B2 are decrease in turn. Shu et al. configured TM/Ti17B18 (TM = V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni or Cu) as cathode catalysts, and found that the bidirectional electron transfer between CO2 reactants and the catalysts [253]. Moreover, by utilizing TM/Ti17B18 as catalyst, the nucleation of Li2CO3 is thermodynamically favorable than that of Li2C2O4. During charging, the co-decomposition of Li2CO3 and C is appealing over the independent decomposition of Li2CO3. Thanks to the bidirectional electron transfer, the TM/Ti17B18 presents distinctive bifunctional activity towards the CO2RR and CO2ER in Li-CO2 batteries. Luo et al. indicate that the excessive adsorption of intermediates on the TiB plane against the decomposition of Li2CO3 [11]. The paired electrons in d orbitals of TMs can mitigate to the unfilled d orbitals of Ti cations in TiB, thereby modifying the electronic structure of TiB, eventually balancing the adsorption of intermediates. Therefore, as illustrated in Fig. 14(i), they incorporated 3d TMs (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) into the basal planes of Ti17B18 MBene, and the resultant TM/Ti17B18 was further coupled with graphene to balance the adsorption strength of intermediates on the surface of these models. Among them, the Cu/Ti17B18/G catalyst delivered distinctly lower polarization (Fig. 14j). They attributed this success to the reduced d-band center and increased antibonding state occupancy owing to the incorporation of Cu dopants. 4.5 Organometallic frame materials Organometallic frame materials hold great promise for serving as advanced catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries [17,92,254–258]. Li et al. summarized the advantages of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as follows: the naturally dispersed metal nodes can serve as catalytic centers to facilitate the deposition and decomposition of discharge products; the regular and uniform micropores can facilitate the nucleation and growth of discharge products; the CO2 adsorption capability of MOFs can be modified by optimizing their pore diameter, porosity, and functionality; a linkage control of the metal centers and pore structures is feasible to elucidate the complex structure-performance relationships for further efficient optimization (Fig. 15 a) [17]. They reported the usage of Mn-based MOFs as porous catalysts for Li-CO2 batteries. By coupling the advantages of high porosity and monodispersed Mn catalytic sites, the Mn2(dobdc) MOF (dobdc = 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) achieves a low charge voltage of 3.96 V, which is obviously lower than those of nonporous MnCO3 and MnO (>4.25 V). Moreover, they found the discharge capacity is positively related to the porosity of Mn-MOFs (Fig. 15c). The high catalytic activity of the Mn-MOF is attributed to the uniformly dispersed Mn-sites, while the bulk MnCO3 and MnO possess limited surface area with less exposure of the catalytic sites (Fig. 15b). The authors realized that the poor conductivity of MOFs is a limitation for their application, and the development of conductive MOF or anchoring them onto conductive substrates is suggested. Generally, the CO2 reduction reaction is considered a two-step process contains the gas-to-liquid CO2 diffusion and the Li+/electron participated reduction of CO2, and the CO2 diffusion is considered as the rate-limiting step [36,39,254,259]. To achieve an efficient capture-diffusion-conversion of CO2, Hong et al. prepared an amino-functionalized Cu-based MOF encapsulated RuO2 nanoparticles (NH2-Cu-MOFs@RuO2) as illustrated in Fig. 15(d) [254]. They felt that the amino-decorated pore wall can effectively adsorb CO2, while the ordered pores provide ample channels for mass transfer. The authors performed DFT calculations to understand the CO2 adsorption in NH2-Cu-MOFs@RuO2, and found that the distance between CO2 molecular and various adsorption sites are 1.53 Å for amino group, 3.07 Å for copper node, and 3.40 Å for benzene ring. For comparison, the copper node and the benzene ring in Cu-MOFs exhibit distances of 2.98 and 3.38 Å, respectively. Moreover, the CO2 adsorption energy of different adsorption sites in NH2-Cu-MOFs@RuO2 and Cu-MOFs are comparatively summarized in Fig. 15(e), which indicates that the amino group has a much higher adsorption energy than the others. They found that the NH2-Cu-MOFs has relatively higher CO2 adsorption capacity of 18.7 cm3 g−1@253 K, 19.8 cm3 g−1@273 K, and 16.3 cm3 g−1@293 K at 1.28 atm, while the values for the NH2-free Cu-MOFs are 13.9 cm3 g−1@253 K, 12.1 cm3 g−1@273 K, and 11.8 cm3 g−1@293 K. The isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) curves were calculated from the CO2 sorption isotherm and indicated that the CO2 affinity of the NH2-Cu-MOFs is much higher that of the NH2-free Cu-MOFs (Fig. 15f), thereby conducing to achieving fast battery kinetics. Phthalocyanines have been widely accepted as a kind of effective catalyst for CO2RR in aqueous solution, but are not suitable for application in aprotic Li-CO2 batteries owing to their solubility in organic electrolytes [91,92,260–263]. Chen et al. prepared a conjugated cobalt polyphthalocyanine (CoPPc) by polymerizing the 1,2,4,5-tetracyanobenzene and Co2+ through a microwave heating method (Fig. 15g) [91]. The elastic CoPPc can be pressed onto carbon cloth current collector and shows high catalytic activity toward the CO2RR/CO2ER. They found that the morphology of discharge products changes from a porous particulate film to a smooth thin film when the current density is raised from 0.1 to 0.3 mA cm−2, indicating the growth mechanism of Li2CO3/C appears to vary with current density. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 15(h and i), the authors demonstrate that the CoPPc-loaded carbon cloth can pair with Li foil to make a pouch cell, which can provide sufficient power for lightening a white light-emitting diode watch band. 5 Conclusions and outlooks Over the past decade, Li-CO2 battery has been under the spotlight of promising battery techniques owing to its inherent ability for achieving energy storage by utilizing CO2 as the medium. The high theoretical energy density of approximately 1876 Wh kg−1 of the Li-CO2 battery offers promising prospects for use in stationary energy storage and powering manned and sealed scientific expedition devices. However, the Li-CO2 battery is still in its infancy and challenged by the large charge/discharge voltage gap, low energy efficiency, and poor rate/cycling capability. These drawbacks are mainly originated from the high thermodynamical decomposition reaction barrier of Li2CO3, limited reversibility of the co-decomposition reaction of Li2CO3 and C, and complex parasitic reactions. The development of advanced catalysts is considered the most urgent and important task for propelling the application of Li-CO2 battery. In this review, we summarized the electrochemical reaction mechanism and the problems discovered in Li-CO2 batteries and concentrated on the recent advances on transition metal-based catalysts. During the catalysis of reversible CO2 reduction and evolution reactions in Li-CO2 batteries, metals typically exhibit distinct evolutionary and operational characteristics: Fe undergoes reversible redox reactions, whereas Co and Ni do not exhibit such behavior. Cu particles tend to oxidize, forming an oxide layer that enhances battery performance. The alloying effect grants solid solution alloys and intermetallic compounds physicochemical properties, such as electronic structures, that are significantly distinct from those of single metals, leading to superior catalytic performance. Metal compounds, including metal oxides, metal hydroxides, and metal sulfides, often exhibit poor intrinsic catalytic activity and electronic conductivity. However, approaches like hetero-interface engineering, defect engineering, and structural optimization offer potential for enhancing their catalytic capabilities. Metal carbides have garnered widespread recognition as promising catalysts due to their remarkable thermal stability, corrosion resistance, cost-effectiveness, chemical stability, and noble-metal-like catalytic activity. Meanwhile, transition metal borides have attracted considerable attention, owing to their metallic nature, accessible active sites, and exceptional electronic conductivity. Metal-organic framework materials often possess monodisperse catalytic sites and abundant pore structures, which are preferred for enhancing catalytic capability; however, they require further improvements in conductivity. Based on these, the key points for the advancement of transition metal-based electrocatalysts for Li-CO2 batteries are proposed, as illustrated in Fig. 16 . First, the macroscopic morphology control and surface microstructure modification of the catalysts are two significant pathways for enhancing their catalytic performance. High porosity and large specific surface area are essential for obtaining high-density active sites, facilitating gas diffusion and electrolyte infiltration, and achieving near-catalyst surface uniform deposition of discharge products [10,45,86]. Constructing porous structured metal-based catalysts or achieving porous structure by embedding metal-based catalysts on conductive porous support materials are both demonstrated as effective pathways to achieve this goal. The surface microstructure such as crystal plane orientation, atomic spatial arrangement, and defects/vacancies, has a significant impact on the catalytic activity of the catalysts [32,170,220,264]. Currently, numerous tactics, including defect engineering, interface engineering, and surface microstructure reconstruction, have been proven effective in enhancing catalytic site density and/or activity. These tactics tune the surface microchemical environment, thereby regulating the adsorption and activation of CO2RR/CO2ER species, lowering the thermodynamic energy barrier for electrochemical CO2 cycling, and optimizing battery reaction pathways. Second, much more research efforts should be devoted to elucidate the evolution of catalyst structure, as well as the deposition and decomposition behavior of discharge products during repeated charging/discharging processes for guiding the design and optimization of catalysts. The state-of-the-art in-situ and/or ex-situ experimental techniques are suggested to gain insight into the entire battery reaction process and achieve the intrinsic correlation among catalyst composition, structure, and performance, thereby providing theoretical support for catalyst design, failure analysis, and optimization [110,114,115,265–269]. In situ characterization techniques offer advantages in understanding the progress of the CO2RR/CO2ER. In situ spectroscopy techniques such as Raman, FTIR, and XRD have been proven highly applicable for qualitative analysis in Li-CO2 batteries, enabling (1) the interpretation of the CO2RR/CO2ER mechanism through the recognition of intermediates, by-products, and final products; (2) the understanding of the evolutions of the battery components such as catalysts, electrolytes, and anodes; (3) the elucidation of battery reversibility and the initiating factors of parasitic reactions. In situ DEMS can simultaneously record the gas consumption/production and corresponding energy input/output, which can be further converted to the ratio between the number of transferred electrons and the quantity of gas that is consumed during discharging or that is evolved during charging, thus enabling an understanding of the reversibility and reaction pathways of the battery reactions. In situ TEM can be used to provide real-time structural and morphological evolution information of solid-state components (e.g., discharge products, catalysts, anodes, etc.) in batteries. For instance, Zhang et al. constructed an all-solid K-CO2 nanobattery based on an aberration corrected environmental transmission electron microscope (AC-ETEM) by using CNTs as cathode catalyst, K attached to a tungsten (W) tip as anode, and the K–O naturally generated on the K anode as a solid electrolyte (Fig. 17 a) [115]. They conducted time-resolved experiments to monitor the morphology evolution of the K-CO2 nanobatteries, and observed that plenty of nanobubbles were formed on the CNT during the first discharge and these bubbles deflated upon charging as shown in Fig. 17(b). Third, it is worthwhile to establish intrinsic descriptors for providing the theoretical guidance and reference to the design of Li-CO2 battery catalysts. Over the past decade, tremendous research efforts have been devoted to advance the development of cathode catalyst for Li-CO2 batteries, but many research efforts are ineffective as they are launched without a clear direction. One of the most pressing missions is to construct a strong correlation, also known as descriptor, between the catalytic activity and the intrinsic properties (e.g., electronegativity, d-band center) of transition metals to guide the design of high-performance catalyst for advancing the development of Li-CO2 batteries. For instance, Guo et al. analyzed the adsorption/dissociation process of key intermediates in thermodynamic and kinetic processes based on DFT theoretical calculations, and found Pd@G with appropriate dx 2-y 2 orbital energy level and electronegativity can effectively weaken the Li–O bond and activate Li2CO3 [156]. They suggested the electronic structure parameter φ = Edx 2 -y 2 / χ can be used as an intrinsic descriptor for predicting the catalytic performance of NM@graphene cathode catalyst (NM@G) for Li-CO2 batteries (Fig. 17c). Moreover, the electronic structure parameter φ, which comprise the energy level of the dx 2 -y 2 orbital state and the electronegativity χ of the noble metal (NM = Ag, Au, Pd, Ru, Ir), has a linear relationship with the decomposition energy of Li2CO3 (Fig. 17d). They prepared the NM@G catalysts using pulsed laser shock-assisted ultrafast synthesis and performed comparative tests under the same conditions (current density: 50 mA g−1; cutoff capacity: 1000 mA h g−1). The Pd@G depicted a low polarization of 0.41 V, which is obviously lower than those of Ir@G (1.47 V), Au@G (1.58 V), Ag@G (1.63 V), and Ru@G (0.63 V), consistent with the prediction results of the proposed descriptor φ (Fig. 17e). The prepared Pd@G also exhibited excellent cycling stability, with a charging voltage less than 3.5 V after 35 charge-discharge cycles (1400 h) at 50 mA g−1 when the cutoff capacity was controlled at 1000 mA h g−1. Fourth, it is necessary to establish standardized testing methods for battery performance and evaluation standards for catalyst performance to enable high comparability among different research works, thereby avoiding extensive trial-and-error studies. The test conditions (e.g., current density, cutoff capacity, cutoff voltage, etc.) are generally set arbitrary. The methods for calculating current density and specific capacity are not unified: some are based on the area of the catalyst, some are based on the weight of the catalyst, and some are based on the total weight of the catalyst and the conductive agent. Therefore, we suggest a Standard-of-Operation should be developed for this battery system to bridge the gap among different studies. Fifth, the practical application of Li-CO2 batteries depend not only on breakthroughs in scientific issues such as sluggish kinetics and limited reversibility, but also closely relates to the cost of catalyst. Therefore, it is suggested to introduce cost and the mass production feasibility as evaluation indicators during the development of high-performance catalysts. This approach is conducive to screening out low-cost catalysts and their compatible mass production processes that can ultimately be applied, guiding scientific research efforts, and contributing to the pragmatic development of Li-CO2 batteries. Finally, given the importance of the electrolyte, anode, and potential safety concerns to the practical application of batteries, we briefly emphasize these concerns here to appeal for more attention to be paid to them. Li-CO2 batteries present potential safety concerns such as thermal runaway, which is usually associated with internal short circuits, leakage (since they generally utilize liquid electrolyte), and other issues arising from improper use or unsuitable operating environments. Although these issues are not directly related to the catalyst, given their importance for the practical application of batteries, we have briefly emphasized them here and provided potential mitigation strategies. Internal short circuits are generally regarded as the most serious safety issue for batteries, commonly caused by lithium dendrites penetration resulting from uneven deposition and uncontrolled growth of lithium during repeated battery cycling. The issue of lithium dendrites is a systematic engineering problem that requires optimization across aspects including the Li metal anode, electrolyte, separator, and others. For the Li metal anode, representative protection measures include: (i) engineering a uniform functional coating layer on the surface of Li metal to facilitate even deposition of Li; (2) utilizing Li-containing alloys or composites instead to suppress dendrite formation; (3) innovating the anode structure to provide more surface area, channels, and sites for Li-ion diffusion and deposition. Lithium dendrites can also be suppressed by optimizing the electrolyte: (1) adding additives to react with the surface Li metal to form an in-situ passivation protective layer; (2) incorporating other metal ions that can regulate Li-ion deposition through effects such as electrostatic shielding; (3) optimizing the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte by adjusting the electrolyte formulation (e.g., types and proportions of solvents, types of lithium salts, concentrations, etc.); (4) developing solid-state electrolytes with high mechanical strength to prevent lithium dendrite penetration. Leakage of liquid electrolyte can also be improved by using solid-state electrolyte or gel electrolyte instead. Furthermore, optimizing the separator in terms of porosity, pore size and distribution, raw material, coating, thickness, etc., can also improve ion migration kinetics, facilitating uniform deposition of lithium ions, and enhance the ability to prevent lithium dendrite penetration. The electrolyte is an important part for Li-CO2 batteries as it provides the internal-circuit charge carrier Li-ion for bridging the anode and cathode. To date, liquid electrolyte is commonly used in Li-CO2 batteries owing to its low-cost, high accessibility, and high technological maturity, but faces several challenges such as leakage, decomposition, and sluggish kinetics. As mentioned above, optimizing the electrolyte formulation can enhance the lithium-ion migration kinetics, stabilize the lithium anode, and improve uneven lithium deposition, thereby inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites. Moreover, it is reported that the nucleation and growth of Li2CO3 can be affected by manipulating the donor number of solvents/additives, the CO2 capturing ability can be strengthened by adding specific additives (e.g., amines), and the reaction pathway can also be significantly influenced by additives in the electrolytes. However, there is currently a lack of systematic research on the correlation between the composition and performance of electrolytes, which poses great difficulties for the development of electrolytes. Furthermore, although solid-state and gel electrolytes can alleviate the leakage and decomposition of liquid electrolytes, they nevertheless suffer from low ionic conductivity, unstable electrode/electrolyte interfaces, and a lack of simplicity in manufacturing processes, as well as technological immaturity with incomplete raw material supply chains. Extensive research efforts should be launched to address these issues, ultimately guiding the design and optimization of electrolytes. The parasitic reactions pose significant challenges for the further development of Li-CO2 batteries. It is reported that the significant corrosion of Li metal anodes also exerts a detrimental effect on the electrochemical performance of Li-CO2 batteries. For instance, Ma et al. found that the Li foil retrieved from a cycled Li-CO2 battery is covered by a corroded layer which is mainly composed of Li2CO3 and LiOH [204]. Li et al. replaced the corroded Li foil of a decayed battery with a fresh one, and the reassembled battery works as normally as the fresh one, highlighting the importance of Li metal anode protection [88]. Lu et al. found that CO2 and electrolytes have a synergistic effect in accelerating the corrosion of Li metal anode [6]. Liu et al. reported that a quasi-solid polymer electrolyte (QSPE) with –CF3 functional groups can effectively inhibit the diffusion of CO2 and electrolyte decomposition by-products to etch Li anode [270]. The –CF3 groups can construct a LiF-rich solid electrolyte interface on Li anode, which induces the uniform and dense deposition of Li to inhibit the deeper Li from being further etched. Lei et al. prepared a lithium ethylenediamine (LiEDA) coated Li anode through a spontaneous reaction between EDA and Li metal by immersing Li foil into EDA- tetraglyme solution [271]. The LiEDA further underwent a crosslink reaction with the electrolyte solvent tetraglyme to in-situ form a gel polymer electrolyte. They demonstrated that the in situ formed gel electrolyte can achieve a decent interfacial contact with both the cathode and the anode, providing effective protection for the Li metal anode against corrosion caused by contaminating gases from the ambient air. Shortly after that, Zhang et al. reported a similar gelation method in Li-CO2 batteries, further confirming its effectiveness in safeguarding lithium anodes in such batteries [272]. Now, Dr. Ma works in the Institute for Advanced Interdisciplinary Research (IAIR), University of Jinan. His research focuses on the fabrication of advanced nanomaterials and their electrochemical behavior/performance in metal ion batteries and metal-gas batteries for the development of advanced electrochemical energy storage systems. Mingjuan Gao is currently a postgraduate student at Institute for Advanced Interdisciplinary Research (IAIR), University of Jinan under the supervision of Wenqing Ma. Her research interests are Li-O2 batteries and Li-CO2 batteries. Jianping Ma received his bachelor’s degree in 1999 from Shandong University. Now, he is the director of the Research Institute of Shandong Sacred Sun Power sources Co., LTD. His current research is mainly focused on the long-life battery technologies for industrial and commercial energy storage systems. Siyu Liu obtained his doctoral degree in condensed matter physics in 2023 from Nankai University. Dr. Liu is currently working at the Nano-Science Center and the Department of Chemistry at the University of Copenhagen. His research focuses on the synthesis of perovskites and their ultrafast excited-state dynamics by transient absorption spectroscopy to develop advanced optoelectronic devices. Lishan Yang got his PhD in inorganic chemistry from Shandong University in 2011, and moved to the Shandong University and then the Institute of Chemistry - Chinese Academy of Sciences as postdoctoral scholars. He is currently a professor of Hunan Normal University. His research interests are in the surface structure control and large-scale preparation of electrode materials. Yahui Yang obtained his PhD from the School of Metallurgy and Environment at Central South University and has worked at Central South University, Hunan Agricultural University, and Hunan Normal University. He is currently a professor of Physical Chemistry at Hunan Normal University. His research topic mainly focuses on aluminum air batteries and the recycling of aluminum smelting waste. Xiangping Chen graduated from Ocean University of China with a bachelor's degree and Central South University with a PhD, and then went to Nanyang Technological University in Singapore as a Research Fellow. Currently, he is a professor in the field of chemical engineering at Hunan Normal University. His research interests lie in the recycling of retired batteries and the design of electrode materials. Tianzhen Jian received her master's degree in 2014 from Northeastern University and her Ph.D. in 2024 from University of Jinan. Her current research interests focus on electrocatalysis and metal-gas batteries.

coredata.dc:description: The Li-CO2 battery has been highly rated as an intriguing technique for balancing the carbon cycle for years, but it is still significantly challenged by the obstacles such as limited reversibility, sluggish kinetics, and poor energy efficiency. Hence, the design and development of advance catalysts that can enhance the kinetics and reversibility of the CO2 electrochemical cycling reactions are considered the imperative tasks. Transition metal-based catalysts are widely considered appealing owing to their unfilled d-orbitals, rich and adjustable valences, as well as processibility. In this review, the working mechanism and the key issues of the CO2 electrochemical cycling reaction are discussed first. Then the strategies for composition and structure design of different type of transition metal-based catalysts are highlighted, including their benefits, limitations, and the ways to implement these strategies. Finally, based on the pioneering research, the perspectives on the challenges and key points for the future development of cathode catalyst are proposed.
